TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it true, as reported, that an Australian diplomat is at present in Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, on a two-week visit approved by the Afghanistan Government? Was the visit carried out secretly to avoid disclosure that the diplomat had applied for a visa from a government not recognised by Australia? On a similar matter, I ask: Is it a fact that Soviet trade missions have regularly visited Australia in the last few months without obstruction but that members of cultural and scientific delegations have been denied visas as a result of the Soviet incursion into Afghanistan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have some information on the matter raised by Senator Button, but part of his question I will need to refer to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I am able to confirm media reports that an officer from the Australian Embassy in Islamabad is currently visiting Kabul, Afghanistan, to undertake administrative tasks. A similar visit took place in April this year. The visit in no way implies recognition of the illegal regime. Australia will continue to withhold recognition of the Karmal regime, which was installed by invading Soviet forces in December 1979. I noted the question with regard to the visits of Soviet delegations to Australia but I have no information on that matter. I will get that information as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I have been reading correspondence from the Minister for Defence relating to 'Kangaroo 81', the exercise to gee up our armed forces to oppose a threat to Australia from an imaginary nation of 'Orangeland' located in the south-west Pacific. Is the Minister aware that the particular country is named 'Orangeland' and that the map of the region really depicts Tasmania turned upside down in the south-west Pacific? Is the Minister also aware that 'Orangemen' are few and far between in Tasmania and that we seldom stand on our heads, although we are stood on our heads every August by the State and Federal governments to ensure that no money is left in our pockets? Is it a fact that the Minister, after a well publicised gathering in Brisbane on the night of 17 March, gave instructions to his Department to turn Tasmania upside down and relocate Tasmania, renamed 'Orangeland', in the south-west Pacific; or is it a result of the insidious influence of the Goon Show over the air waves of Australia? If the latter be the case, can the whole matter be referred to the Minister for Communications so that he might suggest that it be referred to a Senate select committee for investigation and report?

—I am afraid that I am not aware of the map or whether it depicts Tasmania or how the name was chosen. I am sorry if Senator Harradine has jumped to the conclusion that anyone would think that Tasmania was a threat to Australia. It might be a threat to the Government's Budget, in view of the assistance that has been given to Tasmania over the years. I notice that the Budget brought down by the State Government this year does not seem quite to match the cries of doom uttered by the Premier earlier. I will have to ask the Minister for Defence whether he did, at a notable place and on a notable occasion on 17 March, let his imagination run riot or not.

The only thing I can do in these circumstances is refer the matter to the Minister and seek an early reply for Senator Reid.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, relates to the two-month disruption to shipping that has been caused by the strike of the Institute of Marine and Power Engineers. Does the Government recognise that this union dispute is seriously damaging Australia's already doubtful credibility overseas as a reliable trading partner? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the estimated cost of this strike action, which is also causing severe disruption to petrol supplies, particularly in South Australia and is likely to flow over into other States? In the light of the damage being caused and the community's reasonable expectation that governments will protect them from this type of action, does the Minister agree that this sort of strike should not be allowed to arise during the consideration by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of a log of claims? Is it possible for the Government, in the interests of all Australians, to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to prevent this type of action, which is detrimental to all Australians?

—The strike mentioned by the honourable senator is causing widespread concern around Australia, and not least in the honourable senator's State of South Australia where the effects are being felt particularly harshly. The matter was raised in rather similar terms yesterday by another honourable senator from South Australia, Senator Teague, who sought information on the same lines. It is very easy to agree with the proposition that Senator Jessop advanced in his question-that this sort of strike should not be able to arise when matters are under consideration by arbitral tribunals. My understanding of this dispute is that the relevant officer of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has recommended a return to work, and that the strike has persisted notwithstanding that recommendation. I think that whether a form of statutory prohibition would achieve the effect the honourable senator seeks is open to doubt. However, I will refer the suggestion he made to Mr Viner for his consideration.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President, relating to the problems with which we have been faced in that area. I ask the Minister: Is the Government satisfied that sufficient qualified staff is available to the Commission to ensure that the logs of claims and other union representations are dealt with quickly enough?
—I have not heard of any complaints that staff shortages are an element in the problem in this or similar disputes. Again, I will refer that matter to Mr Viner for comment and reply.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is the Government concerned at the recent increasing incidence of fatal crashes of light aircraft in Australia? Is the Government concerned at a set of circumstances which is placing commuter air services, air taxis and the like in increasing economic difficulties? Does that not result in an inevitable erosion of safety standards, despite the best efforts of the industry to avoid that? Will the Government make an early inquiry into those circumstances with the objective of restoring the safest possible standards to the operation of light aircraft in Australia?

—Without doubt the Government has a great deal of concern for any light aircraft crash or, for that matter, any aircraft accident of any kind. Certainly, the Minister has been quite clear in his public statements in that regard over the long period that he has been the Minister concerned. I think Senator Mason may have in mind a recent report from New South Wales in respect of an air crash which took place, I think, last February at Mascot airport. That crash was a very significant one and recently a report on it was presented to the Government. At the moment the Government is studying the matters raised in that report. It would be reasonable to suggest that if matters come forward which require government action, such action will be taken. I need to seek more information from the Minister with regard to the more general questions Senator Mason raised in relation to the erosion of standards, economic difficulties and so on and I undertake to do so.

—Can the Minister representing the Prime Minister inform the Senate of the departments, commissions and statutory organisations which provide subsidised housing to their employees in the form of lower rental or interest payments or other benefits?

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, refers to two questions asked last week by Senators Bjelke-Petersen and Townley concerning Zimbabwe and the presence there of North Korean military instructors. As the Australian High Commissioner to Zimbabwe was recently in Canberra reporting to the Minister and he also recently briefed the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on this matter as well as on the biased anti-Zimbabwean Press reports which were being reprinted in the Australian media, will the Minister bring down a statement on current events in Zimbabwe and Southern Africa for the information of honourable senators? Will the Minister not agree that Zimbabwe, a non-aligned country, whose armed forces are currently being predominantly trained by British instructors, is entitled to invite instructors from other countries, including Australia, to train its armed forces?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I recall the previous questions asked about this matter. It is a fact that the Government of Zimbabwe has agreed to accept an offer of military assistance from the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. The Prime Minister of Zimbabwe, Mr Mugabe, has said that the offer relates to the provision of training and equipment for a brigade of the defence forces of Zimbabwe. North Korean instructors have already arrived in the country. Mr Mugabe has said that other units of the defence forces of Zimbabwe will continue to be trained with the assistance of the British military team, in accordance with the agreement made between the governments of Zimbabwe and the United Kingdom. The Government of Zimbabwe, in announcing its decision, stated that the North Korean offer of military training was consistent with Zimbabwe's policy of non-alignment. We hope that the North Koreans approach their assignment in the same light. The Australian Government does not have under active consideration any involvement in Zimbabwe. I have noted Senator Sibraa's question. I will refer to the Minister the request that he bring down a statement of current views on the matters that were raised by Senator Sibraa. I will see whether that can be done as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CALLAGHAN SPECIAL ASSISTANCE PLAN FOR TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy a question. In the months since the joint announcement by the Prime Minister and the Tasmanian Premier of a review of the Callaghan Special Assistance Plan for Tasmania that State has been under further tremendous and unique economic pressures outside the management control of the State which include a new interstate shipping charges price rise and a $3m loss on this year's apple harvest sales. Has the review machinery now been set up? How is it constituted? What progress has it made? When is it expected to report?

—On 23 August the Prime Minister and the Tasmanian Premier, Mr Lowe, announced that a joint Commonwealth-State review would be undertaken of the Callaghan Special Assistance Plan for Tasmania. The review will be carried out by senior officers of the Department of National Development and Energy and of the Tasmanian Government for the Commonwealth-State officials committee on Tasmania. Advice will be sought from the Centre for Regional Economic Analysis established by the University of Tasmania, with assistance provided under the Callaghan program. Preliminary discussions have taken place between officers of the two governments on the work program for the review. Further, more detailed discussions will take place over the next fortnight. It is expected that the review will be available for consideration by the two governments in early 1982. Should the honourable senator be interested in a copy of the terms of reference, I would be happy to make one available to him.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Having in mind the wonderful work done by the Inland Medical Service in Queensland, a service which is an accepted part of medical care in the north-west of our State, as is the Royal Flying Doctor Service, can the Minister explain why the Inland Medical Service is not funded in a like fashion to the RFDS; that is, with the Federal Government making the money available through the State? I believe Dr Harvey Sutton is the person who is particularly associated with this service. I understand that it has applied for funds. The applications have to be considered in the light of the money available and priorities, including the express priorities of the communities to be served. In the inland that would, of course, include the express priorities of Aboriginal communities. It is in the light of those express priorities that I think the funding arrangements are as they are.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, concerns the prohibition by the Department of Foreign Affairs on the film On Sacred Ground which was the subject of a question asked by my colleague, Senator Coleman, of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 27 August. Since advancement of Aboriginal interests requires co-operation between the Commonwealth and State authorities, it would be contrary to the best interests of the Aboriginals if the Commonwealth Government were seen by a State Government to be acquiescing in the overseas showing of such a film.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —A large part of that question concerns the Minister for Foreign Affairs, whom I do not represent in this place. I will try to pick up those parts of the question which are related to my portfolio. I understand that the original format and objectives of the film On Sacred Ground were decided upon well before the Noonkanbah conflict arose. It was planned originally as a documentary film to study the land rights movement which, at that time, had gone largely undocumented on film. The filming was planned to take place in two stages. The first stage involved the filming of a number of stations and the activities of various Aboriginal communities. By the time the second stage of filming took place Noonkanbah had developed as the focal point of interest for the communities being filmed. I remind honourable senators of the position taken consistently by my predecessor regarding the whole Noonkanbah problem. My predecessor indicated that more reasonable views on each side would have certainly been better for seeking resolution.

ANSWER.PARA: These events at Noonkanbah had the effect of converting a social documentary into a film with significant current affairs content. This had not been originally intended. Film Australia consulted the Department of Aboriginal Affairs during both the research and the filming stages of the film. Film Australia-I am speaking now in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs-has taken a decision to revamp the film in order more effectively to achieve the original objectives of the film. When this work has been done a decision will then be taken about the marketing of the film.

I am not aware that the film was made by Aboriginal people. The honourable senator might tell me if I am wrong. While the original film was screened widely in Australia, it was never offered for television sale outside this country. I understand that this work being done by Film Australia to revamp the film and return to the original goal is something which should be achieved before any decision is taken on its distribution overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Who is to determine the best interests of the Aboriginal people with regard to the screening of this film-the Aboriginal people concerned or officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs?
—The film was made by Film Australia. It is a question which I will address to the Minister for Home Affairs, within whose portfolio the matter rests.

—In view of the human rights and legal implications of my question, it is addressed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the long-standing policy of the Australian Government of opposition to apartheid in South Africa and to recently repeated reaffirmations by the Prime Minister of support for United Nations and Commonwealth declarations and strategies designed to persuade the South African Government to move towards racial and social justice in that country. Will the Attorney inform the Senate whether Australia's objections to South African policies relate only to long standing racial prejudices and practices in that country or, more particularly, to specific obnoxious legislation adopted over the last 30 years which has intensified the political, social and economic suffering of the black and coloured people in South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly Australia's objections to South African policies relate not only to the long-standing racial prejudices and practices in that country but also to a number of other specific legal discriminations, which I propose to mention. In broad terms, Australia's objection to the South African Government's policies are based on our total rejection of the policy of apartheid which has enshrined racism in the South African Constitution. Of course, this discriminatory and exploitative system represents a basic affront to the dignity of man and his fundamental human rights.

ANSWER.PARA: I should like to list some examples of the discrimination practised against black and coloured people in South Africa and the legal authority for that discrimination. These examples do not cover social attitudes or examples of petty discrimination. For instance, there is a denial of suffrage. The South African Constitution provides that only white people have the right to vote for members of parliament. There is a denial of freedom of movement and compulsory relocation. The so-called pass laws and influx control regulations require black and coloured people to have specific authority to enter designated areas for employment purposes and render them liable to deportation to so-called homelands. There is a denial of freedom of association. Blacks may not form political parties. A series of laws, including the Terrorism Act, provide the legal authority.

Freedom to live in areas other than those designated by the Government is denied. The Group Areas Act gives legal authority for most areas to be designated as white areas. Black and coloured people may not purchase houses in these areas. In regard to the denial of freedom to marry, the Mixed Marriages Act and the Immorality Act forbid marriage or cohabitation between people from different racial groups. There is also denial of freedom to work, in that the job reservation regulations under the Industrial Conciliation Act still forbid employment of black people in certain specified occupations, particularly in the mining industry.

Those examples, coupled with the enshrining of the policy of apartheid in the Constitution, give a very clear picture of the sorts of legal discriminations and violations of human rights that exist in the legal structure of South Africa. I say nothing further about the other aspects of the matter, which are really more within the responsibility of the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Acting Treasurer. The Northern Territory Chamber of Industries, representing the commercial life of the Northern Territory, has considerable concern regarding sales tax being charged on the freight component of goods sold in the Northern Territory and the fact that people living in the more sparsely populated areas of Australia are expected to pay higher tax for the same commodities than do people living in the major capital cities. Will the Government give consideration to restructuring sales tax so that it is charged at the point of final manufacture instead of at the final wholesale point so that everybody in Australia pays the same amount of tax for the same commodity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — We have had many suggestions in recent days about the application of sales tax, its collection, the payment of it to the Commissioner of Taxation and so on. That probably signifies that it is difficult to achieve equity without sacrificing simplicity, without increasing the costs of collection and compliance and without creating a number of other administrative problems. The problem referred to by Senator Kilgariff applies also to goods that are sold between capital cities. It ought to be noted that both the Commonwealth Committee on Taxation of 1953 and the Asprey Taxation Review Committee see the present system as a reasonable compromise. For the many goods which undergo several stages of processing, total exclusion of freight charges between any points would be very difficult administratively. For instance, the freight charge would have to be recorded and documented at each stage of processing and manufacture and later dissected between taxable and non-taxable goods. That would add costs to the final price. Exclusion of freight charges on wholesale goods could also disadvantage decentralised industries because freight charges on raw materials can be a necessary cost borne by them but not by their competitors. So we see that other anomalies and difficulties can occur. Some wholesalers arrange to sell their goods ex-store so that freight charges are the responsibility of customers and not part of the taxable sale. I suppose we could discuss a number of such instances.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator has asked that we consider the matter raised in his question. I will certainly refer it, through the Treasurer, to the Commissioner to see whether there is any way in which the suggestion can be accommodated. As I have tried to indicate, it is difficult to achieve equity. It seems to me that the collection of sales tax is becoming increasingly complex as people put their minds to the sales tax Bills that are before the Senate.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. The Minister will be aware that in calculating the income test for a service pension, the Department of Veterans' Affairs counts only half of any disability pension as income and that from January 1982 only 40 per cent of such pension will be so regarded. On the other hand, those ex-servicemen and women who cannot qualify for the service pension but also have a disability pension have all of their disability pension regarded as income by the Department of Social Security when their rate of age pension is assessed. Has the Minister considered removing this anomaly by discounting the value of a disability pension for the purpose of an age pension income test? If not, will he have the matter examined?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will come as no surprise to the Senate that this matter has been raised with me on occasions by people who see it in the same terms as does the honourable senator, that is, as being an anomaly. It is true that only half-shortly the proportion will be 40 per cent-of the disability pension is taken into account when applying an income test for a service pension and that the whole of the disability pension is taken into account in considering a social security pension for a person who is not entitled to a service pension. That distinction results from the fact that in a number of respects repatriation pensioners receive favoured treatment when compared with other Australians. It is a well-established tradition in this country that people who have had war service receive benefits which are not generally available to the rest of the population. The anomaly or distinction to which the honourable senator draws attention is simply part of that pattern. Individual Australians who have qualified for a service pension receive that pension on more generous terms, with regard to their other income, than do people receiving pensions through the social security system.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the suggestion by the honourable senator that we should change the social security system to provide the same concession to people entitled to a disability pension-give them a social security pension on a more favourable basis than is accorded other Australians-that is a matter which has to be determined on balance. On balance the determination has always been that the Department of Social Security should deal with all Australians on an equal basis. That principle has been pursued with some success. The Department of Social Security has tried to ensure that its benefits are available to Australians generally. Historically, we have not always managed that. For example, Aboriginals and migrants have sometimes not had as good access to the social security system as have other Australians. Considerable effort has gone into ensuring that the social security system applies uniformly to the whole of the Australian population. That is a principle which we should breach only with very great caution. Whilst I am quite certain that I shall have to consider the matter over and over again, as it is one on which I receive quite regular representations, and will-as in all matters-always endeavour to keep my mind as open as possible to suggestions that are made to me, I think it likely that the distinction to which the honourable senator has drawn attention will be maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for National Development and Energy relates to the decision by the committee which reviewed Commonwealth functions to hand back to States uranium regulatory powers. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of what consultation, if any, took place with the Uranium Advisory Council but, to put the matter into perspective, there is under review at this moment a total searching of the Atomic Energy Act to see how it can be modernised or rewritten to meet peace time needs in regard to nuclear energy. I think there is a misunderstanding of the powers of the States and the Commonwealth. Let it be perfectly clear that in matters relating to regulatory powers over nuclear issues, in matters related to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, in matters related to the movement of fissile materials from Australia abroad and in matters related to the monitoring of it throughout the world, the Commonwealth has and will maintain its responsibility. The Australian Safeguards Office is part of my portfolio and will remain so.

ANSWER.PARA: Within Australia, within the various States, there is a very considerable quantity of radioactive material, most of it of low grade radioactivity, which is used in industry and medicine day by day. I refer particularly to radioactive isotopes. Responsibility in that case comes primarily within the purview of the State health departments. What is being aimed at is a common code for radioactive materials throughout Australia which will be observed in the ordinary commercial movement and protection of such materials. That is being worked on now. Nothing will be done which will diminish the overall responsibilities of the Commonwealth as, indeed, the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry saw them, as the International Energy Agency sees them and as we see them in terms of nuclear non-proliferation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TOURIST INDUSTRY: TAX EXEMPTION OF VEHICLES

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bjelke-Petersen yesterday asked me a question relating to sales tax on buses used in the tourist industry. I undertook to get information to clarify that matter for her. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Peter Rae proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: To bring about better government in Australia, the necessity for the Parliament to address itself to the real issues raised by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in its report on the Australian Dairy Corporation, such as:
(a) the nature of the administration of the Department of Primary Industry;
(b) the relationship between Ministers and Statutory Authorities;
(c) the accountability of Statutory Authorities and their subsidiaries to the Parliament and to the Government;
(d) the future of Asia Dairy Industries and the Dairy Industry Stabilisation Fund.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the tabling last Thursday of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations we have witnessed an extraordinary sequence of events. That report contained 513 paragraphs. One could be excused for believing that it contained no paragraph other than paragraph 9.38. The first extraordinary event was that within 20 minutes or so of the report being tabled, the former Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Sinclair, rushed into the House of Representatives and made an ill-considered response aggressively to what the Committee's report carefully did not say. One wonders why he should have expected it to say what it carefully did not say. Since then the matter has escalated primarily as a result of the activities of Messrs Sinclair and Anthony.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday the Committee, after a meeting, issued a statement repeating what is the fact in the following terms:
The Committee stands by its conclusion that 'on the balance of probabilities, Mr Sinclair's recollection of the events was not as reliable as that of Mr Webster'.
It should be appreciated that this conclusion does not amount to a finding, one way or the other, that any possible misrepresentation involved in Mr Sinclair's account of events was deliberate.
Let me further identify what the Committee did not say. In paragraph 9.38, which was carefully drafted, we said:

The Committee concludes that on the balance of probabilities, Mr Sinclair's recollection of the events was not as reliable as that of Mr Webster. In other words, it appears to the Committee that on the balance of probabilities, Mr Sinclair was told of the terms of the compromise-
I emphasise the words 'was told of the terms of the compromise'-
which necessarily involved a continuing breach of GATT.

That does not say that he was told expressly of the continuing breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, nor was there evidence which would have enabled the Committee to say that Mr Webster asserted at any time specifically that he mentioned a continuing breach of GATT. What Mr Webster told the Committee in clear and unequivocal terms was that he had told the Minister of the terms of the compromise reached in Manila on 15 November 1976. That compromise necessarily involved a continuation of the breach of GATT. Any Minister worthy of the position would, on being told of the terms of the arrangements, recognise that fact, particularly having regard to his prior knowledge of the existence of the breach. Notwithstanding this, Messrs Sinclair and Anthony and others chose to conduct the debate in the House of Representatives yesterday upon a basis of attempting to rebut that which the Committee had not stated. By adopting this tactic they were able to attempt to cast doubts upon the validity of the Committee's finding on the basis that Mr Webster did not tell us specifically that he had referred to the breach of GATT. The wildest accusations, the misrepresentation of the Committee's report and the clear and deliberate quotation out of context such as that engaged in by Mr Killen, which was most regrettable, I believe--

TALK.START.PARA: —A shocking speech.

—Thank you, Senator Missen. All those things were part of that which happened yesterday to which I take the strongest exception. Time does not permit me to answer each of the various points raised. I will therefore concentrate on rebutting two new matters which were introduced in an attempt to besmirch the credibility of Mr Webster-a man already under police investigation at the instigation of this Government-and, thereby, apparently to prove the credibility of Mr Sinclair. I regard the innuendo that Mr Webster should be regarded as unreliable because he is the subject matter of a police inquiry as unworthy of those who would assert it. There is a clear presumption in this country that people are innocent until they have been proven guilty. That does not say that the Committee accepted every word in its totality which Mr Webster uttered in evidence to it. To suggest so, as was done yesterday, is absurd. The main point was not adverted to in yesterday's debate, apparently because most people were unfamiliar with the facts, the evidence and the documents-as they were with the report. However, I am not so sure that that can be said of Mr Sinclair. Mr Anthony referred to a document he tabled which was an extract from a record of interview in Melbourne on 13 October 1976, during which Mr Webster is noted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a discount of $25 per tonne . . . had been provided until recently when skim milk powder prices reached the minimum specified in the GATT-SMP arrangement. . . . the ADC had invoked the Majeure clause in the contract in order to discontinue sales to the Philippines at prices which would have been inconsistent with the GATT minimum.

Mr Anthony concluded from that document that Mr Webster had given the Trade Development Council information that was wrong. He pointed to the fact, as did Mr Sinclair, that it was not until subsequently, on 9 November, that Mr Sinclair instructed Mr Webster to cease the breach of GATT. Far from this information being wrong, it is totally corroborated by the correspondence available to Mr Sinclair. I repeat that it is totally corroborated by the correspondence available to Mr Sinclair. I would like to refer briefly to that correspondence. I start with a telex of 27 September 1976. I remind honourable senators that on about 31 August the Department of Primary Industry, having had the information available to it since the beginning of April 1976, finally woke up to the fact that there may have been a breach of GATT going on and took some action. Acting with great speed and alacrity, after some four months, it sent a telex to the Australian Dairy Corporation suggesting that action could be taken in relation to the matter. That telex was received at the beginning of September. I refer to a telex of 27 September 1976. It is from Mr Uytengsu and it is addressed to Tony Webster. It states:
Believe your action to arbitrarily cutoff or reduce supply and change arrangement without reasonable notice due to your own peculiar internal problems is unfair and prejudicial . . .
In other words there is the confirmation in a telex from Mr Uytengsu that Mr Webster had already taken action to terminate the breach of GATT. I turn to a letter of 14 October.

TALK.START.PARA: —What date was that?

—That was 27 September 1976. However, a letter of 14 October, which I will table, is far more important still. It is a letter from Mr Uytengsu of Holland Milk Products Industries Inc., a copy of which was sent to the Honourable Ian Sinclair. I will quote from that letter. It is addressed to Mr A. A. S. Webster. Amongst other things, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Now to suddenly cut us off on your commitment as to milk supply in such a short notice is unfair to a customer who is also your partner.
You will also recall that during your visit last September 1976-

In other words, it is the confirmation, again from Mr Uytengsu, that Mr Webster had acted in September after receiving the telex from the Department of Primary Industry. I go on to more interesting correspondence. On 14 December 1977, in a letter from Holland Milk Products to Mr Webster, the following statement appears:

There can be no doubt that this type of strained relationship cannot continue to go on as partners and I must now indicate to you that I am no longer prepared to accept your presence on our Board, and so long as you remain the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, our company will not buy one single pound of Australian milk powder.
There is a futher statement which reads:

I must therefore demand that you arrange for me to have a meeting sometime during late January in Canberra with the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr. Ian Sinclair, or your First Assistant Secretary, Mr A. Wallace, First Assistant Under-secretary of the Department . . .

A carbon copy of that letter was sent to Mr Ian Sinclair. I refer to that letter only because it is the next letter which is of real significance. It is a letter dated 23 December 1977 from Mr Webster who, at that time, would have been unlikely to believe that this inquiry would take place and that he would one day be accused of the misrepresentation and lack of credibility of which he was accused yesterday in the House of Representatives. In that letter addressed to Mr Uytengsu he stated:

I can assure you that the Australian Minister for Primary Industry and the First Assistant Secretary, Mr Wallace, are fully aware of the facts and have been throughout, and there has never been any suggestion of impropriety on any individual's part.

That statement relates to the actions which had led to the cessation of the contract and the relationships between the Australian Dairy Corporation and Holland Milk Products in the sale of skim milk powder. I repeat that in December 1977 Mr Webster said:
I can assure you that the Australian Minister for Primary Industry and the First Assistant Secretary, Mr Wallace, are fully aware of the facts . . .

There are one or two other small matters in relation to that evidence which I do not think time will permit me to refer to in any detail. Those are letters which are available and which have been known to the Department of Primary Industry, copies of most of which have been sent to Mr Sinclair. Yet those statements besmirching the credibility of Mr Webster were made by those two Ministers yesterday-accusing him on the basis of this extract from a record of interview with Mr Tony Webster, Chairman, and Mr Alan Page, senior marketing officer of the Australian Dairy Corporation, in Melbourne on 13 October 1976. They made their case substantially rest on this attack on Mr Webster. I ask the Senate and the gentlemen themselves: Who is it now who may be regarded as a reliable witness? I repeat: Who is it now who may be regarded as a reliable witness? Mr Webster commenced breaking off the contract in breach of GATT in September early after it had been drawn to the attention of the ADC by the Department.

There can be no doubt that at the time in October 1976 when Mr Webster said what he said, which was that he had taken action in the Philippines in relation to this contract, that the ADC had invoked the majeure clause. We then find that some new act intervened in this situation between 13 October 1976 and 15 November 1976 when, surprisingly, Mr Webster negotiated a contract which involved the continuation of the breach of GATT until the end of June 1977. What was the act, of which we are aware, which took place between 13 October and 15 November 1976? It was the interview with Mr Sinclair. What was said by Mr Norwood, the General Manager of the Australian Dairy Corporation? He said that it was a very touchy subject and that there was great concern as to what would happen if this contract were suddenly broken off and Australia was forced to find a new outlet, at a time of overproduction around the world, for its excess amounts of skim milk powder. That evidence is in the transcript of evidence at pages 184 to 188. That was one act which perhaps caused Mr Webster to reconsider whether he should continue on the course he had already so clearly and demonstrably set in train to cut off Australia's continuing supplies of SMP at a price below the world GATT minimum.

Let us look at the reasonableness of the interpretation placed on Mr Webster's letter of 19 November 1976 to Mr Sinclair, which specifically refers to the letter of 14 October 1976. I have the letter of 14 October 1976 to Mr Webster from Mr Uytengsu. That letter makes no reference to a breach of GATT. How is it, then, that Mr Sinclair concluded, when he received a letter, that at the meeting in Manila on 15 November an amicable arrangement had been made in relation to the matters raised in the letter of 14 October and that that proved conclusively that there was no continuation of a breach of GATT? It is absurd to suggest that that was a reasonable interpretation. There was no reference to a breach of GATT. Mr Sinclair had received copies of the correspondence in September and October and yet pretends innocence that he really first became involved in the matter on 9 November. He had known for months and took no action. One asks: Why? I say all of this in relation to the first item of the matter of public importance. There are so many unanswered questions and such an apparent loss of memory by Mr Sinclair that one wonders how and whether it would be possible for Mr Webster to have the result of a police inquiry impartially and objectively considered by people who have treated Mr Webster in the way in which he was treated yesterday in the House of Representatives.

I pass briefly to what I trust my colleagues will be talking about in more detail, that is, the history of a disastrously inept administration in the Department of Primary Industry and a free-wheeling subsidiary which behaved as if money was going out of fashion and accountability was an unknown word, a Department which behaved as if it could see no evil, hear no evil and speak no evil, and it did not really matter what else happened. There was not either on the Australian Dairy Produce Board an observer from the Department or on the Board of the Australian Dairy Corporation a member who was a senior officer of the Department, and all these things happened year after year during the period the Committee investigated these matters. What action was taken by the Department? What steps were taken by the Department to correct this situation? The first memorandum was in 1972 and there was another in 1975, but was anything done? Was anything done other than putting some suggestions on paper? Did we see any real change? By 1977 the Department got around to discussing whether there might not be some guidelines. I gather from what Mr Nixon said last night that it might now have introduced them-in 1981, only about nine years after the obvious, clear necessity for action became apparent to every person who was in any way involved in the consideration of the administration of the affairs of the dairy industry by a Government agency, its subsidiaries and the Department.

A breach of GATT existed for 15 months, from April 1976 until June 1977, to the available knowledge-I emphasise available knowledge-of the Department, because an officer was present when the two matters were discussed at an adjacent time at a Board meeting, but, he says, he never thought to put the matters together. For 15 months that breach of GATT continued, notwithstanding the fact that at one stage the Department said to the ADC that it should stop and at another stage the Minister said it should stop. Yet apparently nobody took any steps on behalf of the Department, nor did the Minister take any steps; nor did they seem to say yesterday that they thought they had to take any steps even to inquire specifically whether the breach of GATT had stopped. Is it a case where the Minister, perhaps in the best interests of the primary producers and the skim milk powder processors of Australia, decided that the contract should be honoured? Mr Uytengsu was certainly becoming most unhappy, most threatening, about the attempt to break the contract.

One wonders what really happened at that discussion on 9 November which led Mr Webster to go to negotiate the agreement he did on 15 November in Manila, which involved the continuation of the breach of GATT. What the Committee did not say in any way was that Mr Webster had told Mr Sinclair of the continuation of the breach of GATT. The Committee said that he had told him of the facts which necessarily involved, to anyone who liked to apply himself, a continuation of the breach of GATT. I wonder-I conclude with this-why it was that Mr Sinclair, having received the report, went straight into the House to defend himself against a charge that was not made by the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike my learned Committee Chairman, Senator Rae, I do not normally take the view that we here in the Senate are the last bastion of rational and civilised politics in this country and that we need to defend ourselves against the hairy barbarians of popular democracy beating on our doors from across King's Hall. Equally, I take the view that the Senate committee system is one of the more rational and substantial achievements of our parliamentary system. The many reports that over the years have been generated by Senate select and standing committees have been, with no exceptions that I can think of, fair and balanced, well researched, well reasoned, and reasonably lucidly constructed and written. I believe that the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries does fall squarely within this description. There is nothing in it from which we as Committee members, or indeed the Senate as a whole, need backtrack or resile. It is a matter of profound disappointment that Government spokesmen have chosen to deal with the political embarrassment undoubtedly caused by some of our findings in that report not with reasoned argument but rather with misrepresentation, calumny and invective.

SPEECH.PARA: The report, of course, is about many more things than simply the credibility of Mr Sinclair. Some of those things-certainly not all-are listed in the title of the matter of public importance set down for today, and they are the issues that will be picked up and pursued by my colleague Senator Walsh. That said, it can scarcely be denied that one of the real issues raised by the report is the credibility of the former Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Sinclair, in claiming, as he has, that he was not told of the actual terms of the arrangement to wind up the $25 rebate and that, as a result, he was not a party in any way to the continuation of the breach of Australia's international treaty obligations. This is the issue which occupied the House of Representatives yesterday and which occasioned the extraordinary outpouring of vitriol on the Senate Committee-both its findings and its individual members-that we yesterday witnessed. This is the issue which, accordingly, I believe most urgently needs to be put back into its proper perspective. This is the one on which, like Senator Rae, I will concentrate. As we all know, the Committee's finding stated:
The Committee concludes that on the balance of probabilities, Mr Sinclair's recollection of the events was not as reliable as that of Mr Webster.

We did leave entirely open the question of whether there was anything deliberate about any misrepresentation that may have been involved, on some views, by Mr Sinclair's account. However, that fact has been systematically ignored by those who have mounted the defence on his behalf.

We are dealing here with very complex questions of fact, and it is easy to get totally bewildered by claims and counterclaims, by quotes and counterquotes. I suspect that that is at least part of the response of those who witnessed or read about yesterday's debate. I believe that the issues can be best untangled here today and that the respective credibility of the Committee's findings on the one hand and Mr Sinclair's defence on the other hand can be best assessed if we break the elements of the dispute into five distinct areas: Firstly, the meaning of Mr Webster's evidence; secondly, the credibility of Mr Webster as a witness; thirdly, the credibility of Mr Sinclair's answer in the context of the whole sequence of events from which that answer was derived; fourthly, the effect of the evidence of the two departmental witnesses, Messrs Wallace and O'Bryan; and, finally, the effect of the documentary evidence that has been called in aid, apparently, by Mr Sinclair in his reference to 'all the minutes and documentation that were available to the Department of Primary Industry'.

Let us look at each of those points in turn and try to get the debate on this particular and rather complex matter back on the rails. Let us deal first of all with the meaning of Mr Webster's evidence. Was it in fact claimed by Mr Webster that Mr Sinclair had been told in substance of the actual terms of the termination agreement or was it rather the case, no doubt as a result, as Mr Spender would say, of my inadequate cross-examination, that he was allowed to get away with just hinting at this without actually committing himself to unequivocal statements with which he might later be caught out? That is the question here. I raise a few quick points in relation to it. The first one is that, obviously, there has been an extraordinary selectivity here, as elsewhere, in the quotations which have been employed in support of that particular thesis. I do not believe that any fair minded observer could be left in any doubt, especially upon reading the evidence of Mr Webster as a whole and not just the segment of it that is extracted in the text of the report, that the 'facts' and 'details' which Mr Webster says he put to the Minister were the facts about the continuation of the breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

I refer the Senate to three extracts from among many which could be chosen from my cross-examination of Mr Webster in order to refresh the minds of those who no doubt have been poring over the report so assiduously over the last few days. I quote from page 147 of the report:

TALK.START.PARA: —Was the Minister made aware of the fact that the GATT minimum was still being breached by virtue of the post-15 November arrangement?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Webster-I advised the Minister of the facts.

The exact same word is used. The same expression is used. And this, of course, follows a long sequence of earlier cross-examinations in which Mr Webster had made it perfectly clear what the facts had been and had identified them as such. I quote now from page 148 of the report:

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister endorse the solution that you had reached in Manila or did he tell you to go and renegotiate it because GATT was clearly continuing to be breached?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Webster-The Minister noted what I said.

That followed, when read in context, a clear indication by Mr Webster of what he had in fact said on just that issue. The long preceding answer makes that clear. Finally, here, on page 149 of the report, is perhaps the most direct, explicit and unqualified assertion of them all, following my question in the following terms:

TALK.START.PARA: —Was the decision to continue those shipments through until June 1977, notwithstanding the breach of GATT, brought to the full knowledge of the Government?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Webster-It was aware.

How could one be more unqualified? How could one be more precise than that? Obviously the Government defenders of Mr Sinclair believe that the Webster evidence can be subject to no other possible interpretation than that which it has, of course, universally been given. They would hardly otherwise have taken such pains to try to destroy Mr Webster's credibility, a point to which I will come back.

Let me say this in further elaboration of this particular point about the meaning of Mr Webster's evidence. I readily acknowledge that my cross-examination of Mr Webster, which took place in the initial exploratory phase, it needs to be remembered, of the inquiry, and in a context where the claims here being made for the first time certainly caught us somewhat by surprise, could possibly have been supplemented by further questions designed to produce even more unequivocal answers. I note in this respect that there seem to be no complaints from Mr Spender about my skills in cross-examination later in the evidence when it came to testing Mr Wallace. It was only by my continuing to press and draw him out in the interests of fairness, after he had made a complete fool of himself, that any kind of direct and unequivocal answer was produced. I wish Mr Spender's greater court experience was matched by the intellectual capacity to employ it in this Parliament.

Certainly I gave consideration personally as to whether Mr Webster should be recalled to give supplementary evidence. I certainly would have been only too happy to insist on this had any doubt been raised by Mr Sinclair, or anyone acting on his behalf, as to what Mr Webster was actually saying when Mr Webster's evidence was first put to him. But the point is, of course, that no such doubt was raised and, as a result no such re-examination seemed to be necessary.

Senator Peter Rae's letter to Mr Sinclair on behalf of the Committee dated 25 March, drew attention to what he described as 'a clear discrepancy' between Mr Webster's evidence and Mr Sinclair's recollection, as that recollection had been expressed in Mr Sinclair's initial letter to the Committee of 16 March. But nowhere in that initial letter from Mr Sinclair, or in Mr Sinclair's reply of 22 April to the second Rae letter, or in Mr Sinclair's subsequent personal explanation of 7 May-all of which are fully set out in the text of the report-is the point taken that Mr Webster's evidence is not clear and unequivocal. The claim that the Webster evidence is imprecise and meaningless has all the earmarks of a recent invention designed to help the Minister extricate himself from the hook on which it is all too obvious he has impaled himself.

I turn to the credibility of Mr Webster as a witness. Mighty efforts were made, of course, by Mr Sinclair's defenders to impugn Mr Webster, to destroy his reputation and character, in order, of course, to destroy the credibility of the evidence that he gave. Reference was made to an unsigned memorandum of 13 October in which Mr Webster is said to have told certain persons interested in Australia's trade policy that action had been taken to discontinue Australia's sales of skim milk powder to the Philippines because of the GATT breach. It may be that Mr Webster did not tell the full story to those whom, here, he had no obligation to do so of just when that particular discontinuance was likely to become operative. A more likely interpretation, however, is that, as Senator Peter Rae has said, Mr Webster had embarked already on the process of discontinuing, of severing, our sales arrangement with the Philippines on 13 October when he spoke to these gentlemen, but that following the meeting with Mr Sinclair on 9 November he changed course. That seems to me to be a much more likely interpretation. It appears that the famous memorandum, the new memorandum, the one piece of documentary evidence newly appearing on the scene in yesterday's debate, will prove to be one of those double-edged swords which has returned, Viner-like, to decapitate its wielder.

It may be, however, if the worst light is put upon that event of 13 October, as Mr Norwood attested and as is also referred to in the O'Bryan letter, and of course as was pointed out in the House of Representatives, that Mr Webster did not tell the Board of the ADC either of all the details of the termination arrangements or when the sales were to actually cease. That may not have been unusual, regrettably, in Mr Webster's dealings with the Board, and certainly it is no more defensible for that. It may again prove, of course, to be the case that Mr Webster will in fact prove to be in trouble on matters of financial administration when the long awaited reports of the Auditor-General, and more particularly of the police, are eventually tabled. Certainly there were some not very well concealed hints and suggestions darkly made to this effect by some of the more high minded of Mr Sinclair's defenders in the other place.

The point is, of course, that all this kind of material, with the one exception of the memorandum of 13 October, was known to the Committee and was taken into account in the course of our deliberations. The Committee was well aware of a number of Mr Webster's managerial and other limitations. We have indeed been highly critical of Mr Webster at several points in that report. But we were anything but naive about what might be said and what might be thought about Mr Webster's credibility. We took that very much into account in finding as we did.

The third point, of course, is the credibility of Mr Sinclair's claims in the context, as I have said, of the sequence of evidence from which they arose. Mr Sinclair did not put his evidence on oath but he did make a solemn statement to the House of Representatives and I, for one, am not disposed to make much of the difference. Clearly his evidence has to be given great weight; but it should not be accepted blindly. The one thing I think, perhaps more than most other things, that told against it to the Committee was the total situation, the total context in which the claim by Mr Sinclair came to be made. Let me remind the Senate of the undisputed evidence as to the chronology of immediately relevant events. In April 1976 the ADC knew for the first time of the impending price drop and that this would result in a breach of GATT. In late August or early September, perhaps earlier than that but certainly no later, the Department became aware of the breach and requested the ADC to do something about it. During September 1976, on Mr Wallace's explicit written evidence early on, the Minister was notified of the breach. On 9 November 1976, following discussions which we are told by Mr Norwood in evidence were at length between Mr Webster and the Minister, the Minister requested, not directed-on his own account in the letter to Mr Sinclair on 16 March this year-Mr Webster to take action to remedy the situation. On 15 November 1976 the rebate termination arrangements were negotiated in Manila. On 19 November Webster's letter to Sinclair was received, saying that an amicable solution had been reached.

So much, of course, is clear. What is in dispute is whether, following Webster's return, there was any meeting between Webster and Sinclair in the course of which the actual terms of the settlement were in substance communicated to Sinclair so that he knew that, although sales were to be terminated, the breach would in fact continue for another six months until Australia's accumulated rebate credit was exhausted. It appeared to the Committee to be beyond reasonable comprehension in all the circumstances that Mr Sinclair, despite his well known indifference to some matters of administrative detail, would not have had the curiosity to find out how it came to be that this very difficult and, as Senater Peter Rae has said, very sensitive contract had been able to be so amicably terminated. The matter was one of very great gravity, although one could be forgiven for thinking the ADC and the DPI thought otherwise, given the delays which occurred in their taking serious action on this, not to mention the delay of the Minister between when he first became aware of it in September and when he gave his direction, or request, whatever it may have been, to Webster on 9 November. It was also an issue which was obviously pregnant with gravity so far as the possibility of embarrassment politically, domestically and in terms of our international trade reputation was concerned.

There was, on all the evidence, despite what was said yesterday in the House of Representatives, a mountain of skim milk powder crying out to be moved and accordingly pressure of an enormously significant kind was coming from the dairy industry. The matter had been the subject again of high level discussion, as we know, in the Department and of course on the Minister's office. Mr Uytengu's hostility to any variation of the contract and indeed to all the cast of characters involved in this matter was, as Senator Peter Rae has told us again today, well known. The termination of the contract was not something that could just be unilaterally accomplished by a stroke of the pen. We had a high-powered negotiating team which had just been dispatched to Manila and had just returned.

Does anyone really believe that under these circumstances Mr Sinclair's curiosity was so minimal that he simply took absolutely at face value the proposition that an amicable solution to the problem had been reached? Mr Norwood, now of course Manager of the Australian Dairy Corporation, then a member of the Manila negotiating team, put the real probabilities of the situation very neatly in a passage in his evidence which occurs, as it turns out, just a couple of paragraphs before that which was quoted supposedly against the Committee in the House of Representatives yesterday. On pages 185 and 186 of the transcript Mr Norwood is reported as saying:

If we had told the Minister we had a problem and obtained his agreement to a course of action, I would find it very surprising if the result of those negotiations were not conveyed to the Minister in some way. Our files show that that was done neither by Telex nor by letter, nor was any official advice conveyed to the Department. But knowing it was such a touchy subject, I would be surprised if we did not relay the information in some way.
The transcript goes on:

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we entitled to assume that firstly the Department and secondly the Minister were made aware of the final washup arrangement made with Mr Uytengsu and of the intention to continue giving Mr Uytengsu a $25 per tonne rebate in breach of the GATT minimum price?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Norwood-Logic would tell me that the Government would have been advised of the outcome of the debate with Mr Uytengsu, even if not of its implications: That the arrangement was to continue for some time.

I think the fourth point-the evidence of the departmental witnesses, Messrs O'Bryan and Wallace-can be dealt with much more quickly. It appeared likely from Webster's evidence that one or other of those officers had been present at the meeting which Webster claimed had taken place. Mr O'Bryan's evidence, either orally to the Committee or in the letter which it was claimed, entirely erroneously, had been suppressed, made it clear certainly that he had not been party to any such meeting and knew of no such meeting. He also made it clear that he was away on sick leave at the crucial time, between 11 October and 29 November 1976, which period, of course, included the crucial fortnight immediately after the return of the negotiating team from Manila. I think Mr Wallace's evidence, which did finally produce a clear-cut denial which has been much relied upon, is perhaps best left to speak for itself with a little help, as we have had in recent days, from Senator Peter Rae. Suffice it to say that demeanour is crucially important in assessing any witness's credibility and that Mr Wallace's demeanour and the way he prevaricated in his answers were such as to leave no one who physically attended that hearing in any doubt but that his evidence was worthless.

Finally, I come to the fifth point, the famous documentary evidence which Mr Sinclair claimed existed in departmental files and would exonerate him completely. We were somewhat disconcerted on the Committee to find that there was apparently such a body of crucially probative documentary evidence. We had been told on several occasions that no such documentary evidence existed. We waited with bated breath for the revelations in the House of Representatives yesterday, but when it came time to put up or shut up in the House of Representatives yesterday the dog failed to bark. 'There was no documentary evidence as to any such meeting,' said Mr Sinclair, 'and therein', said Mr Sinclair triumphantly, 'lies the proof that no such meeting occurred'. The fact that there might be another explanation for the absence of a departmental minute of this kind does not seem to have occurred to Mr Sinclair. It was all, of course, a diversionary tactic. Any reply will do, however misleading, if it takes the heat off. No document has been produced, with the exception of the memo of 13 October, which we have already dealt with, which was not fully taken into account by the Committee in its findings. What I am sure about, when all is said and done and the history of this matter is written, is that this Committee and its report, despite all the abuse that has been heaped upon them, will stand a lot more respectably, a lot more honourably and a lot more proudly than the reputations of those who have sought to malign them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had proposed to speak towards the end of this debate because I had understood that we were debating a matter of public importance in the terms that were submitted by Senator Peter Rae. It does seem to me, however, having listened to Senator Peter Rae and Senator Evans, that we are indeed debating not 'the nature of the administration of the Department of Primary Industry', not 'the relationship between Ministers and statutory authorities', not 'the accountability of statutory authorities and their subsidiaries to the Parliament and to the Government', not 'the future of Asia Dairy Industries and the Dairy Industry Stabilisation Fund', but we are debating yet again the credibility of Mr Sinclair and the finding of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations as set out in paragraph 9.38 of its report which was, of course, the first finding that called forth comment in this chamber after Senator Peter Rae put down the report in this place only last week.

SPEECH.PARA: To that extent we are not debating an examination of how this country ought to be run. Let us not fool ourselves or try to fool anybody else. We are debating questions which are purely political and which were described by the Chairman of the Committee when he was talking about criticism of the fact that the Committee had made a finding on credibility. On 22 September he said:

In other words we did all those things which juries around Australia are every day asked to do. Having assessed that evidence we reached a conclusion on the basis used in proceedings of the civil courts of Australia, that is, the standard of proof . . .

And so on. In other words, this Committee has set itself up as a court. It has made findings on disputed questions of fact. It has made findings of law. For example, it has made findings as to the validity or otherwise of a contract. I think that in trying to move from the role of a Senate committee, from the role of a parliamentary committee to the role of the courts, the Committee has made a fundamental mistake. Senator Evans smugly asserted that he will be judged kindly by history, but the outcome may well depend on the future role of this Parliament in its treatment of Australian citizens and whether it is seen as an oppressor or indeed as a parliament which protects the people.

For, I suppose, 10 years now I have been discussing with Senator Peter Rae the role of parliamentary committees. That is not an academic matter in this country. Since the Senate set out on its new committee activities and the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange brought before it some people who were potentially under threat of prosecution and asked them questions, there has been debate in this country about the role of parliamentary committees. In the few minutes I have in this debate I do not have time to expand on that matter, but I raise before the Senate what I see as a very serious question-whether it is proper for the Senate Committee to have set out to be judge, jury and prosecutor and to assume all the other roles that it assumed in this matter. I would like very quickly to refer to the sorts of difficulties which arise in this area and which were mentioned in the Australian Law Journal back in the early part of the 1970s when this matter was being so vigorously debated. I shall read a short passage from that journal. I ask honourable senators to apply this passage very soberly to the sort of debate which has taken place in this chamber and in the other place since this report was brought down. I quote a very small extract referring to the powers of the Houses to punish. I think this is a power which has been discussed in the context of committee activities. The journal stated:

There is no calm, deliberative atmosphere such as exists in a court of law. There is no independent tribunal trained to disregard irrelevancies and emotional responses. There is only the prosecutor, represented by a large number of members of the house of parliament, mostly unfitted by training for the task or bound by party discipline to vote as directed and resentful perhaps of the conduct of the person to be punished.

I know that every member of the Committee will reject that but I ask them to consider soberly whether, as in the words of the Chairman, they are entitled to act as a jury in these matters and whether they should hold out themselves as having the ability to make the sorts of findings which have been made. Because time is very limited I will address myself briefly to the two major areas which have arisen in the debate. One is not directly raised in the matter of public importance, that is, the criticisms of the Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair. The other is the substance of the matter of public importance, which is the question of the administration of the Department of Primary Industry.

I think the key point in the second area is that the criticisms of the Department, which I have been told in this debate extend over ten years, are criticisms which to a large extent have already been recognised by government over a period and which to a large extent have been acted upon by government. The central points of the speeches which have been made so far relate to the question of Mr Sinclair's credibility. Mr President, those matters have been addressed at some length in the House of Representatives. I would commend the debate in that place to your attention, and particularly the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) which I think is an extremely good analysis of why the finding of the Committee can be called into doubt. I do not think any lawyer would doubt that if this were a judgment of a court-we might wish it were-it would be appealable.

Let us look at the facts which are beyond dispute and which are apparent from the report itself. It is accepted by the Committee that Mr Sinclair issued an order that as the existing arrangement breached the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade it had to cease. There is no argument about that. The Minister learned of the breach-there is criticism because he did not learn of it early enough-and he said that it had to be brought to an end. There is evidence from Mr Norwood that Mr Webster had said that the Minister had acknowledged the reason the contract had been entered into with the rebate and pointed out that if the arrangement now breached GATT it must cease. Mr Sinclair advised the Committee that he could recall discussing the situation with Mr Webster in November 1976 and requested him to take action to rectify the situation so that the GATT minimum price would be observed. They are matters about which there is no dispute. The Minister found out about the breach and ordered that it cease.

There is no dispute about that fact-the Committee reported this-that the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation was sent on a special trip to the Philippines to implement the request of the Minister. That is a second undisputed fact. The Minister ordered the practice to cease and the Chairman went off to the Philippines to do something about it. There is no dispute about the fact that an agreement was made on 15 November. The third schedule to the report contains that agreement. The terms of it might lead one to doubt that the Minister's request or order had been complied with, but the fact is that an agreement was made. There is no dispute that, within a matter of days, Mr Webster wrote to Mr Sinclair in these terms:
It was possible for us to arrive at an amicable solution to our outstanding difficulties.

That is the only piece of writing which has been produced by anybody which bears directly on this fundamental point. The great amount of concern that has been expressed about what other evidence might be available really relates to the fact that in the great mass of written material which exists there is absolutely nothing to suggest that Mr Sinclair was advised otherwise than in accordance with that letter. That is the sole piece of direct corroborating evidence. I note that Senator Evans is nodding his head. There is no dispute about that set of facts.

The odd set of facts is that the agreement of 15 November is one which doubtfully removed the breach of GATT, although that is a matter on which the report is uncertain. I think there is room for some uncertainty as to whether the agreement did continue a breach of GATT. That merely underlines the difficulty of a finding which suggests that Mr Webster somehow put Mr Sinclair in possession of enough facts for him to be quite clear a breach of GATT had continued. It is quite clear, when one looks at the third schedule to the report, that there is room for argument that that arrangement would not contravene GATT. But that is merely a measure of the complexity of the question that has to be determined.

The one piece of writing on which there is no doubt is that which confirms that there was an amicable solution reached in relation to the outstanding difficulties. The difficulty which caused the trip to the Philippines was, of course, the difficulty over GATT. Questions were then pursued by the Committee. The examination of the Public Service witnesses produced evidence which was, if anything, supportive of Mr Sinclair. Firstly, there was the evidence that Mr O'Bryan was possibly one of the public servants present. But he clearly indicated that he was not present at any such conversation.

The Committee described the evidence which it chose to doubt as evidence which only lightly supported the Right Honourable Ian Sinclair. The fact is that any evidence which came before the Committee was evidence which buttressed the evidence of Mr Sinclair. The only justification which can be given for a finding which is adverse to Mr Sinclair's recollection-I stress that it is a finding which is adverse to his recollection only-is that the Committee chose to have a very poor opinion of one of the witnesses who appeared before it. That is the sole straw on which the Committee was able to rest its case that the finding should be adverse to Mr Sinclair. The whole of the evidence which is beyond doubt-the whole of the evidence which is clear and unequivocal-favours the Minister. The evidence which goes against him is equivocal. I believe the finding which has been made by the Committee is a finding which is, therefore, not justified by the facts.

In the brief time which is available to me I wish to refer to the recommendations of the Committee. The recommendations go substantially to the administration of the Department and of statutory authorities. I mention some of the matters which have been given attention by the Government. For a more detailed catalogue I refer the Senate again the speech, which was given by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) in the other place yesterday. The matters which were referred to the Committee arose out of the fact that the Government had already taken action on the matters which were of concern to it. The matter was referred to the Auditor-General by the Minister for Primary Industry. The Minister sought the intervention of the Auditor-General in these matters. Several reports have been received from the Auditor-General and, in fact, action has been taken with respect to the recommendations of those reports, including a reference to the police with respect to matters which appeared to give rise to the possibility of offences having been committed.

Among the recommendations of the Committee-they concern matters already acted upon by the Government as a result of implementing recommendations contained in the reports of the Auditor-General-are the following: Firstly, there was a recommendation that there should be a clear definition of the powers, authorities and delegations of the Australian Dairy Coporation and the boards and management of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd. This has been done. The position in respect of each body is now clearly defined. This was done prior to the receipt of the report. There was a recommendation that there should be an upgrading of systems, documentation and approval processes. A revised system of budgetary control and improved documentation standards has been introduced. A recommendation was made that future borrowings by ADI are to be subject to guidelines developed by the Minister for Primary Industry and the Treasurer. These are in the final stages of development. In the meantime, no borrowings are being approved without the specific approval of both Ministers.

There is a recommendation that investments by ADI are to accord with guidelines determined by the Minister. These are being finalised along with the borrowing guidelines. In the meantime, no investments are taking place without the Minister's specific approval. The recommendation that the charging of expenditure and the allocation of costs between ADC, ADI and the joint venture companies be delineated has already been established by the boards of the ADC and the ADI. One of the main themes in the Committee's report was the control of expenditure by these two bodies. Many of the specific matters raised by the Auditor-General in his report to the Minister have also been acted upon with a consequent tightening of financial control.

May I in conclusion say that when one looks at the response of the Senate when this report was first put down, one is left with a very clear answer to the query that Senator Peter Rae raised as to why Mr Sinclair should go into the Parliament and respond to the report at such short notice. I remind the Senate that within minutes of the report being put down in this place serious allegations were being made about Mr Sinclair, he was being accused and senators who had not read this report were endorsing it and endorsing the Committee for its careful work. It sits ill in the mouth of senators to condemn a man for defending himself when he was damned by people who had not even read the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.
