TALK.START.PARA: —For the record I want to make it known at the outset that I was not, as Senator Peter Rae put it the other day, at any relevant stage a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations which produced this report. I did not contribute at all to the preparation of the report. I have had, however, a deep and sustained interest in the matters that it covers and I did table in October of last year extracts from the Auditor-General's report which the Committee acknowledges on page 288 was probably critical to its subsequent investigation. I might add that for tabling those documents I was villified by Country Party Ministers and by agro-industrial politicians such as Messrs Pyle and Bennett. They were supported by a slothful, sycophantic and, in some instances, corrupt agricultural media.

SPEECH.PARA: I support Senator Rae's proposal which essentially is that the Parliament should examine and debate the issues raised by the report. The scandals exposed last week, and previously, are due partly to structural defects in the bodies concerned but mostly to the negligence, incompetence and continual deceit of the Country Party Ministers who have controlled the authorities in question and to their vigorous endeavour to protect their cronies and lackies in the Australian Dairy Corporation-an effort maintained right up to yesterday when they turned on some of those cronies and lackies in a desperate attempt to save their own skins. Yesterday the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) accused the Committee of having presented in its report a very limited analysis, of being silent on many big policy issues and of focusing on certain negative aspects in the management and control of the Australian Dairy Corporation. There was certainly plenty of the last item but I have not time to cite examples.

In spite of what Mr Anthony said, the Committee did make recommendations on a number of important matters. Among others, it recommended that the Dairy Corporation should present a biannual financial report. It recommended that the Auditor-General should register as an auditor in Hong Kong in order that he could audit the books of the subsidiary, Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd, as well as its parent corporation. The Committee recommended that reports on section 63P audits-that is, special audits-should be made available to Parliament and to the public. That is in contrast, I observe, to the practice followed by the present Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) who has been sitting on the report of a section 63P audit for more than two years. It also recommended that Asia Dairy Industries should not have wider powers than the Dairy Corporation, which is its parent, and of course demonstrated the ways in which it does at present have wider powers. It recommended that the ministerial power of direction should be explicitly written into the Dairy Produce Act and that when that power is used it should be exercised only in writing and that the facts should be reported to the Parliament sooner or later. It described the present Deputy Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation as a man who was guilty of both stupidity and dishonesty. Are those acceptable attributes in the Deputy Chairman of the Corporation? Does the Government accept the findings of the Committee with respect to Mr Pyle? It it does, does the present Minister believe that stupidity and dishonesty are acceptable attributes in the Deputy Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation? If he does not believe it, when will he exercise his power under section 8 of the Dairy Produce Act to dismiss Mr Pyle, whom the Committee of this Senate has found to be stupid and dishonest, from that position?

What is the Government's reaction to any of those recommendations of the Committee that I have mentioned and the others that I have not mentioned? Today from Senator Chaney we had, to a very limited extent, some response. Yesterday in the House of Representatives from the Ministers responsible, past and present, we had no response at all. The Government's response to the questions I have raised is a matter for wide-eyed conjecture with the possible exception of its response to the mandatory tabling of section 63P audits. Since the present Minister has been sitting on such an audit report for more than two years one could quite reasonably assume that the Government has rejected that recommendation of the Committee in advance. Though Government Ministers who spoke yesterday in the House of Representatives were mute on matters of policy, Country Party Ministers in particular were certainly verbose on other matters-such as smearing the Committee and blaming everyone but themselves and the Department of Primary Industry for the villainies and peccadillos disclosed in the report. The primary defence was that Mr Sinclair did not know what was going on at the time that many of the matters were taking place. He in fact did know, and I will deal with that later. But even if he did not know, what is the judgment of the Government on this view on ministerial obligation which was presented at the 38th Summer School held from 29th to 31st January 1972:

But if a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia, and if the Minister were unaware of it, the Minister should accept responsibility for the mistakes of his department and offer to resign.

That was the opinion presented nine years ago by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). Is that still what guides the Government on these matters? Are breaches of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and tax evasion in foreign countries by Australian government agencies matters of real importance to Australia? If they are, has Mr Sinclair offered to resign? If he has not offered to resign, why does the Prime Minister not enforce his own standards and insist on Mr Sinclair's resignation? What indeed has happened to the forthright principles on ministerial responsibility enunciated nine years ago by the Prime Minister? There was no response yesterday; there will be no response today; there will be no response tomorrow.

A basic rule of behaviour guiding Country Party politicians which I have observed on innumerable occasions over the years is this: When in trouble say anything that comes into your head that gets you off the hook for the moment and worry about the future later. That rule has certainly been applied in this case. For example, when questioned on 15 November 1979, about the release of the Auditor-General's report on the Dairy Corporation, Mr Nixon said:
. . . the practices that caused concern to the Auditor-General are no longer relevant.

Not only was that not true at the time he said it; it was not true 18 months or two years later. The practices which caused concern were relevant then and they are relevant still. The next week, on 22 November, Mr Nixon said that he would not table the document because 'the delicate and sensitive commercial report should not be made public'. He responded to a telegram from me on 7 December 1979. In response to my request to examine the report in his office, since it allegedly contained delicate sensitive commercial information, he replied:

It would be contrary to proper conduct in such matters to disclose the contents of the reports until full consideration has been given to the question of further action being taken consequent upon the reports.

I note, among other things, the contradiction between the reference to the need for further action and his answer two or three weeks before that the practices were no longer relevant. But that was not the end of it. On 10 April 1980 he was again questioned on the tabling of the report. He said:
The Auditor-General has advised me not to table them.

That matter was taken up by the Senate Estimates Committee with the Assistant Auditor-General, who denied what Mr Nixon had claimed. That denial was further confirmed by letter dated 24 April 1980 to Senate Estimates Committee A, as it was at the time, in which the Auditor-General stated that there were two types of reports, one auditing the normal functions of government, the tabling of which was mandatory under the Audit Act, and special section 63P audits, the tabling of which was optional. The Auditor-General added:
. . . but no recommendation was made on whether or not the report in question should be tabled.

The same rule of 'say whatever comes into your head to get you off the hook for the moment' has been applied following the release of the Senate Committee report. Ironically, in the House of Representatives yesterday, Mr Sinclair repeated the Nixon furphy about the Auditor-General when he said:
When I was Minister for Primary Industry, the Auditor-General advised me that the initial report he provided to me could not be tabled in this House.

I do not believe Mr Sinclair any more than I believed Mr Nixon when he used precisely the same excuse. I challenge Mr Sinclair to produce any documentary evidence that the Auditor-General so advised him. In this instance, I ask Senator Chaney to note, there is on record directly contradictory evidence from the Auditor-General with respect to the advice allegedly given to another Minister but which in fact was not given. Continuing with the application of the rule, Mr Sinclair said last Thursday, immediately after the report was released, that its conclusions were contrary to all the minutes and documentation in the files of his Department. Of course, he was immediately challenged by Senator Rae saying that, if that were so, Mr Sinclair's officers had perjured themselves before the Committee because they had said there were no such minutes and documentation.

Senator Rae having blown that alibi out the window, on Monday morning Mr Anthony shifted his grounds of defence when he said that Mr O'Bryan's letter had cleared Mr Sinclair, and also-this was produced yesterday-that the extract of the record of a meeting of the Trade Development Council on 13 October 1979 had revealed that Mr Webster had told the meeting that the rebate had ceased under the majeure clause of the Holland Milk Products Inc. agreement. Both Mr Anthony and Mr Sinclair claimed that these matters clearly showed that Mr Webster was a liar whom only a particularly naive or vindictive committee would have believed in preference to the Minister. A number of questions arise if that minute of October 1976 is so vital to the case. It would seem extraordinary that the Department of Trade and Resources did not draw the Committee's attention to it when it wrote a lengthy letter to the Committee on 7 April this year. Of course, more importantly, Senator Rae has already shown in this debate that all the information disclosed there was on the public record. This tends to confirm what the former Country Party Leader John McEwen is claimed once to have said with respect to his successors: 'The trouble is that one is bone lazy and the other is dumb'. Mr Sinclar continued to say anything that came into his head. Yesterday in the House of Representatives he said:

Let it be known throughout this place and everywhere else that my successor, the officers of the Department of Primary Industry and I are most concerned that the abuses which have taken place apparently within Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd, in any of its associate companies or in any of the affiliate companies . . . should be identified . . .

In contrast, when Mr Hayden first raised this matter in the Parliament, Mr Sinclair launched a vicious attack on Mr Hayden the very next day. I quoted from that last week and I do not have any time today to quote further from it. That pious and sanctimonious statement made yesterday by Mr Sinclair shows that he must be the last straggler on the road to Damascus. There is too much telling evidence already on the public record for Mr Sinclair to be saved by the eleventh hour sanctimony which was uttered yesterday in the House of Representatives and which I have just quoted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, believe it or not, this is the first opportunity I have had to congratulate you on your election to the position of President, and I now do so. It is a pleasure to see you sitting in the chair, Mr President. In speaking on the matter of public importance, I bring to the attention of the Senate the fact that the subject we are supposed to be discussing is the necessity for the Parliament to address itself to the real issues raised by the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on the Australian Dairy Corporation. In fact, to date very little has been said about that subject. So far the debate has concerned the credibility of the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) rather than the subject of the report, and I will say something shortly about that and then deal with the subject.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Webster is under investigation and I therefore wish to say very little about him. Certainly, in no way would I wish to prejudice that investigation, although, with all due respect to the Chairman of the Committee, I noticed today that he seemed to go to great lengths to defend Mr Webster. I hold no brief for Mr Webster but, having heard him and heard the other witnesses-Norwood, Wallace and O'Bryan-on the subject that everyone seems to want to talk about, I supported the finding of the Committee. I do not resile from that finding that, on the balance of probabilities, Mr Sinclair had a conversation with Mr Webster during which he was told the terms of the compromise. The terms of the compromise necessarily involved a continuing breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. That does not say that he was told there was a continuing breach of GATT.

Mr Sinclair advised the Committee, and confirmed to the House, that he did not recall being told by Mr Webster that there would be a continuing breach of GATT. Of course, that is not an unreasonable thing for him to say. Many people are claiming that the Committee has found that Mr Sinclair was lying when he said that. The Committee did not so find. Individual members of the Committee, including the Chairman of the Committee today and Senator Evans the other day in the Senate, and other members of the Committee--

TALK.START.PARA: —And today.
—Yes, Senator Evans confirms that he spoke today.
—There was a Press statement yesterday.

—I will come to that in a moment. In any event, the members of the Committee have been at pains to point that out. I observe from my reading of the Hansard record of the House of Representatives debate yesterday that some honourable members who rose to defend the Minister for Communications failed to read and understand the words of the report sufficiently to understand that simple point. Yesterday, the members of the Committee responsible for the report got together and issued a Press release which contained the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: It should be appreciated that this conclusion does not amount to a finding one way or the other that any possible misrepresentation involved in Mr Sinclair's account of events was deliberate.
All members of the Committee confirmed that. I do not wish to say more on the subject. I think having heard the evidence, that, on the balance of the probabilities, it was a reasonable finding.

A matter raised by Senator Chaney prompts me to state that I am concerned that Senate committees should not develop into star chambers. I have expressed to various senators on the Committee my concern that witnesses should be protected. I am concerned also that we provide a public forum and that accusations are made against people who may not be able to defend themselves. To my mind the Senate committee system is in no way run like a court. We have six senators who listen to witnesses and may cross-examine them at will. Committee members often interject. Senator Evans and I are not unknown, in the midst of cross-examination, to engage in repartee on political points. Generally, a hearing is not in any way conducted like a court of law. To suggest that our Committee was sitting as a court of law is, in my view, quite wrong. In any event, if the Senate Committee had been so sitting it ought not to have been. I repeat my conviction-I am sure that honourable senators in this chamber who are concerned about civil liberties and the rights of members of the public will agree with me-that Senate committees must not go down the path of becoming star chambers. One wonders where, otherwise, the committee system might end up 50 years hence. It behoves each and every one of us to be careful when we are on committees to make sure that we do not follow that path.

Again in relation to something that was said by Senator Chaney, I wish to express my belief that, if our Senate committee system is to work, it ought to have the benefit of some ministerial input. It seems to me that far too frequently Senate committees consider at great length, and in detail, matters which involve government yet the Government first hears about them when the report is tabled. If the Government was aware of the situation, and wanted to, it could take action on its own initiative, but it is really up to the Senate to devise a system whereby some governmental input is assured. For example, since this report has been tabled a number of Ministers have said to me: 'Look, it is just impossible, Austin, to make a note of all the people who call in to see you and tell you things that are going on. Unless you sense immediately that there is a problem you do not bother to make a note about it. You just say: 'That's all right, go ahead, that's fine'. I understand also that on parliamentary sitting days, with quorums being called, divisions occurring, Cabinet meetings taking place and departmental officers calling in, Ministers are really overwhelmed by the volume of work. Perhaps my colleague, Senator Withers, who is to follow me in this debate, and Senator Douglas McClelland, both of whom have been Ministers, will be able to add to that comment. We are not Ministers, we are back benchers, so we do not really grasp these facts. This is a matter on which perhaps Ministers could have had some input, especially in terms of our recommendations.

I turn now to some of those recommendations. They are really important and represent what this debate is all about. It is necessary for the Parliament to address itself to the real issues raised in the report. For example, paragraph 15.10 of the report concluded:

. . . that it is impossible for a statutory authority to have absolute unfettered commercial autonomy. It has obligations and duties imposed on it through being created by an Act of the Commonwealth Parliament and its funds being raised through compulsory levies which are also raised by Commonwealth legislation. The rights and privileges are not conferred without creating obligations and duties in return.

On many occasions my Committee found that the directors of statutory authorities clearly do not appreciate their responsibilities to the Parliament. More often than not they think that if they have a bit of a conversation with the Minister that is adequate to tell the Parliament what it is all about. Those of us in the Parliament recognise that that is not adequate to confirm to the Parliament the matters with which the statutory authority is dealing. The statutory authority is created by the Parliament, not by the Executive. Our recommendation 15.12 states:
The relative responsibilities of the Minister and of persons appointed to the Corporation could be clarified . . .

There is not the slightest doubt that in many cases the officers, and in particular the directors of these corporations, do not fully understand their responsibilities. Some of the difficulties created thereby are immense. For example, when a director of an authority who is perhaps a dairy farmer and selected to represent dairy farmers is appointed to the Australian Dairy Corporation, how must he vote when faced with a difficult decision involving the Dairy Corporation, the manufacturers and the dairy farmers? Should he vote in accordance with his own beliefs as a dairy farmer and in support of dairy farmers, or should he look at the actual responsibilities of the Corporation? Of course Parliament would say that he ought to look at the responsibilities of the Corporation because once he has been--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Department's representatives on the authority?

—Senator Gietzelt asks about the departmental representatives on the authority. That is another major problem. The Committee is concerned that a departmental officer who is responsible to a government can be appointed to a board and end up with a vote on the board. How is he to vote on such a difficult matter? Frankly, the Committee considered finally that it would be far better if such a person held a consultancy position so that he would not have to exercise the right to vote. As a consultant on the board he would have a pipeline direct to the Minister, or through the Department to the Minister, and could report on what the Corporation was doing about a particular matter. He would not then be subjected to problems of confidentiality when told things.

SPEECH.PARA: That was another problem that the Committee had to face. Clearly, the Australian Dairy Corporation comprised representatives of three different bodies. From time to time one body would not want to let the other body have information. For example, were directors who represented manufacturers to be given confidential information about the price of a product that Asia Dairy Industries was selling overseas? Such information was being kept from directors. In fact, one of the criticisms made by the Committee of Mr Webster is that on occasions he acted as a complete dictator and took very essential decisions about a number of matters without in any way referring them back to the board, or reporting to any other member of the board, because he was trying to keep the information from certain directors. All of those matters are met squarely in the report, which contains pages and pages of recommendations-all of which represent an attempt at reasonable compromise.

I do not suggest that the Government ought to adopt the recommendations as if the Committee had been able to set down, in biblical form, a series of rules. The Committee is an ordinary committee of the Senate. It may very well be that once Ministers have seen the recommendations they will say: 'But the Committee has failed to grasp the fact that our duties obligate us to do this or that, so we are unable to carry out the recommendations made on this matter'. On the other hand the Committee, by making these recommendations, has set out the problems for the Government and has offered proposals for their solution. I am sure that the Government will consider the recommendations in the same way as that in which they have been presented by the Committee. I hope that in due course we will arrange for improvements to be made in the relationships between statutory authorities and the Parliament, statutory authorities and the Minister, and statutory authorities and the Government.

Another matter I raise, so that honourable senators can understand what we are talking about, is that of the creation of subsidiaries by statutory authorities. In committee investigations we have found that 42 subsidiaries have been created by statutory authorities. In many cases those subsidiaries have been given wider powers than have been given to the statutory authorities which the Parliament created. In no case was the creation of those subsidiaries of statutory authorities even reported to the Parliament at the time of their creation, although frequently we subsequently found out that they had been created. These are matters of vital concern to which the Senate, the House of Representatives and the Ministry should turn their minds. I think it would be far better if the Parliament were to address itself to those issues raised in the reports rather than to the one matter which everyone keeps talking about and which, quite frankly, is so insignificant that it could have been left out of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been concerned for some time by the cavalier manner in which not only some members of the Executive but also the bureaucracy have been making a farce of our parliamentary system. No honourable senator can deny that at times on both sides of the chamber there has been an expression of concern that the parliamentary system as we know it not only is under constant attack but indeed in many respects appears to be wilting. That has been the view of the Parliament-it certainly has been the view of some honourable senators-for some time. Indeed, it was one of the reasons for the establishment of Senate standing committees. For instance, in this Parliament honourable senators have sought certain information by way of questions on notice. If honourable senators look at the Notice Paper today, they will see that questions that were placed on the Notice Paper as long ago as November 1980 remain unanswered.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been told from time to time by departments through their Ministers that too much time would be taken up by departmental officers in providing answers to the questions. Staff ceilings have been imposed by the Government, not only on government departments but on the Parliament itself. An Estimates committee was told last week that the Government had set a staff ceiling for the Senate, a ceiling well below the actual staff level that is needed to effectively serve the Parliament.

In this sessional period alone, on at least six or seven occasions Senator Peter Rae, in his capacity as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, has had to move that certain annual reports of departments or statutory corporations for the year ended 30 June 1980 be referred to his Committee so it can seek an explanation as to why the report was presented 14 or 15 months late. Ministers have not seemed to care. No explanations have been given by them to the Parliament as to why the reports are late. That is because, in fact, no explanation has been provided to the Ministers concerned by their departments. They have been and are being snowed by the bureaucracy. Judging from ministerial overreaction to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, which is now under consideration, they expect Parliament to remain quiescent and to turn a blind eye to the system that they are allowing to run down.

The Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair)-the former Minister for Primary Industry-instead of accepting the report as a constructive criticism of what has become a sleeping system about which no one seems to care has, as it were, shot from the hip. Ministers have been tolerating the lack of accountability to the Australian public, through the Australian Parliament, by departments and statutory corporations for far too long. That, in short, is the gravamen of the Committee's report and the recommendations contained in it. I suggest that that situation has been occurring because some Ministers have been in office for too long. They operate under the 'born to rule' syndrome. They have become far removed from their base, namely their constituencies and the parliamentary system. They act as though they are bricks which are mortared into the wall of bureaucracy. Departments seem to regard their Ministers as the Godfather.

The inferences to be drawn from the statements made yesterday by National Country Party Ministers in particular and also by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen)-namely, that because all members of the Committee were not present at all meetings of the Committee no one can take any notice of the report of the Committee-show simply how far removed they are from a knowledge of their parliamentary committee system. Indeed, I would have thought that the Minister for Defence would not have dared to speak on the subject because it was he, as Minister for Defence, who recently had a run-in with the Country Party member for Kennedy, Mr Katter, the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, when he, the Minister, would not allow one of his officers to appear before that parliamentary committee.

Ministers know, and if they do not know they should know, that like Parliament itself parliamentary committees are subject to a quorum arrangement. If we did not provide for quorums the committee system would not work; indeed, Parliament itself would not work. But whilst they try to detract from the work of the Rae Committee, of which proudly I was a member, by stating that only four of the six members of the Committee were present at certain times, they conveniently ignore that a transcript of the evidence that was taken was made available to and read by the members of the Committee; that there were minutes adopted at every committee meeting; that there was a constant going over of the evidence given to the Committee; and that all members of the Committee were consulted at all stages of the drafting of the report.

As a member of the Committee, I can tell the Senate that there were many hours of deliberation on the part of the Committee members as to the manner in which the report would be presented. Apart from that, Ministers should also know that there is a Senate Standing Order, Standing Order 36AA, which states:
The quorum of a Committee shall be three.
It goes on to state:
A Standing Committee shall have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members . . . The quorum of a sub-committee shall be two Senators.

When Ministers complain that only four out of six members were present at certain times, they are telling the Parliament and the public that the committee was acting firmly within the Standing Orders laid down by the Parliament. The Government knows that if that Standing Order did not exist, not one of the Senate committees would be able to function. All that Mr Sinclair and Mr Killen have done is to confirm the bona fides of the sittings of the Committee.

As much as Mr Anthony, Mr Sinclair and Mr Nixon, in particular, have whinged about the Committee's report, they have only themselves to blame for the Committee having initially to accept the reference. They cannot blame the Committee or the Senate for that reference. It was because of their lack of accountability to Parliament and the concern of Parliament, in particular the Senate, about the attitude of the Department of Primary Industry and the statutory corporations associated with it-namely, that they were not being administered effectively and that they were not providing the Minister or the Parliament with information to which the Parliament was entitled-that the reference to the Standing Committee took place. After all, there was a departmental officer on the corporation concerned, one of whose tasks was to report to senior departmental officers and the Minister, as appropriate. They are not my words; they are the officer's own words. Indeed, when the Australian Dairy Corporation was created on 1 July 1975, a departmental officer was appointed to the board to 'represent the Australian Government'. The officer appointed by the Government in 1979 to represent the Australian Government, when giving evidence before the Committee, said:

In regard to the functions, duties and obligations of the Government representative on the ADC, I am not aware of any formal set of guidelines applying to the Commonwealth Government representative but I understand them to be
-to report to senior Departmental officers and the Minister as appropriate.

Senator Rae has already tabled a letter written to Mr Uytengsu by Mr Webster, the chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, on 23 December 1977. As Senator Rae has emphasised, these are the words that appear in that letter:

I can assure you that the Australian Minister for Primary Industry and the First Assistant Secretary, Mr Wallace, are fully aware of the facts and have been throughout, and there has never been any suggestion of impropriety on any individual's part.

A carbon copy of that letter was sent by Mr Webster to Mr Wallace who became the Minister's own representative on the board of the Australian Dairy Corporation. For that reason, the Minister, and particularly the present Minister for Communications, cannot now say that the Committee has been used as an instrument against them as individuals.

I ask honourable senators to read the introduction to the report. It was lack of information given to the Parliament that made the Parliament concerned about the way in which the Department of Primary Industry was being administered and the way in which statutory corporations appeared to be ignoring the doctrine of accountability. The Committee said in its introductory chapters that as far back as 1975-six years ago-criticisms were being made by the Department of Primary Industry of Asia Dairy Industries' relationship with and its reporting to its parent statutory authority and the Australian Government. Then, in September 1977, two articles appeared in the Australian Financial Review which for the first time disclosed the existence of a rebate arrangement on the sale of Australian skim milk. Understandably, those articles appeared as a result of the Australian Dairy Corporation meeting the expenses of three journalists to go to South East Asia, ironically on a public relations exercise. But it should be remembered that an officer of the Department of Primary Industry appointed by the Minister, which appointment obviously was agreed to by the Executive Council, was placed on the board of the Australian Dairy Corporation whose job it was to keep the Department, senior departmental officers and the Minister advised.

Thus, in October 1977 the Committee conducted a preliminary investigation into the affairs of Asia Dairy Industries and the Australian Dairy Corporation. The Committee decided to withhold making a detailed public investigation and to await the receipt of subsequent annual reports and the Auditor-General's report. Then, for reasons which have not been made entirely clear to the Committee, the Minister for Primary Industry instructed the Auditor-General on 28 March 1979 to undertake an audit under section 63P of the Audit Act into Asia Dairy Industries, a subsidiary of the Australian Dairy Corporation, on which body there was a departmental officer who, in his own words, said it was his job to report to the Minister. Obviously, for that decision to be taken by the Minister, the Minister himself must have been concerned. If the Minister was concerned, surely it was axiomatic that the Parliament and the parliamentary committee that initially conducted an investigation into the affairs of this subsidiary also should be concerned. We were told that certain matters which were the subject of the Auditor-General's report had been referred to the Australian Federal Police for investigation. As we have said in our report, we, the members of the Committee, studiously have avoided seeking evidence which may have impinged upon matters which were the subject of police investigation. But what I say is that the Minister himself obviously was concerned, the Department obviously was concerned and surely it was our responsibility as members of this Parliament to be concerned.

The Committee at all times acted most responsibly. The detailed inquiry was undertaken into a number of important matters which are the responsibility of this Parliament. Our conclusions have been based on the evidence that was given to us. The basis on which we worked was set by the comments of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare which in a report to this Parliament said:

Parliament is the body responsible for ensuring that public servants are accountable for their actions and that Ministers retain their level of accountability to Parliament and people. Clarification of procedures and reallocation, or addition, of resources will be needed from time to time to enable the concept of accountability to retain its meaning. There is increasing doubt about the ability of Parliament to bring to account Ministers and public servants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate neither to defend the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations nor to attack the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair). I had some hand in the drafting of this matter of public importance. Having listened to the nonsense that has gone on in both chambers in the last two days, I think it is time that the Parliament started to address itself to the real issues raised by the Committee's report.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose, for a start, one ought to look to the purpose of Senate committees. My understanding of their role and purpose in life is that they, as far as they are able, discover the facts and make recommendations. They are not established to be persecutors or prosecutors of people, nor are they to sit in judgment of events. I say to my friend and colleague Senator Chaney that there is a deal of truth in what he said in his opening remarks. I say to him also that if the standard of Senate committees is slipping it is most likely because they merely reflect the political standards of this country. We cannot expect the troops to behave well when the generals on both sides of both Houses behave even worse.

I say this because to date the debate has been about Sinclair and Webster. If we were to ask ourselves why the standard is slipping the answer lies in the fact that Australia is totally corrupted in a moral sense by partisan politics in this country. As much as we are morally corrupted by partisan politics in this country it does not do the media much credit to follow our low example. This is why the debate has been of the standard it has ever since the report came down. I do not think the debate so far reflects much credit on the Parliament or on most of the individuals who have been involved. I suppose I will not have much credibility either by the time I am finished. We are so cursed with partisan politics that we are prepared to adopt standards concerning the behaviour of our own colleagues and to make accusations about the behaviour of other people which ought not to be tolerated in a civilised parliamentary democracy. This is one of the worst developments in this country.

Of course, I know that perhaps occasionally Senate committees may be accused of acting in the role of persecutors and prosecutors. For goodness' sake, I have never noticed any inhibitions on the part of the executives within this Parliament-both government and Opposition executives-to denigrate and defame people outside this place under parliamentary privilege. In fact, some of the worst behaviour recently has occurred in this Parliament in respect of Mr Webster; a man who has not been charged, let alone convicted. I say to my friend and colleague, Senator Chaney, with all the persuasion I can bring to bear that before he lectures parliamentary committees I suggest that he lecture his Cabinet colleagues. Having got that off my chest, I return to what this debate is supposed to be all about, and that is parliament addressing itself to the real issues contained in the report. Some of those issues are listed in the proposal. It includes:
the nature of the administration of the Department of Primary Industry;

I believe that any fair-minded person, not reading the report but having the patience and the time to plough through the evidence which has been tabled in the Parliament, would have to come to the conclusion that the administration of that Department is not terribly red hot and has not been for a large number of years. I do not single out only that Department; I think it is a disease which runs throughout the Commonwealth Public Service. The Public Service is like the Parliament. It is good, bad and indifferent. It has loafers and hard workers. God help Laurie Oakes, I suppose it even has some drunkards in it, as this Parliament has. It is no better than any collection of 80,000 or 100,000 people. Anyone who has listened to the debate so far would think that the people in the Department of Primary Industry are either a bunch of totally inept, incompetent people or are working for Archangel Gabriel. It is part of the moral corruption of partisan politics in this place that we cannot even have a sensible non-partisan debate on the real defects in the administration of the Department of Primary Industry. The proposal also includes:
the relationship between Ministers and Statutory Authorities;

Nobody wants to tackle that because it is a bit difficult, a bit hard. The Finance and Government Operations Committee has done its best to try to point out the matters which ought to be investigated and which Parliament ought to take seriously. There is no way that members of parliament will take that matter seriously when they can, with much glee and excitement, spend their time throwing muck at each other. That is jolly good partisan politics, but I do not know whether it will advance better government in Australia. I hope that the Parliament addresses itself to the real issue of the relationship between Ministers and statutory authorities. I was once upon a time a Minister-a very improper one, I might add, by the standards of those days but perhaps not by the standard of these days. Standards change; as with obscenity laws and R rated movies et cetera. These things have a changeability about them according to the moral sense of the community for the time being.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can expect better of you under Peacock, can we?

—Oh, er-you could-well, I don't-oh, well. Did I fudge that nicely? I hope I fudged that sufficiently well. The Committee would not claim to have any infallibility about it. My friend, if not my colleague, Senator McClelland and I have both been Ministers responsible for statutory authorities. Differing statutory authorities have differing relationships with Ministers. Much of the relationship depends upon the personality of the Minister and the personalities of the heads of the statutory authorities. I do not think any serious work has ever been done on this very vital subject, which is seen as especially vital when one considers the enormous intrusion of statutory authorities into the life of this nation. At least the Committee in this report has addressed itself to some of those problems in an attempt to get some serious debate in the community on those problems. The proposal also includes:

SPEECH.PARA: the accountability of Statutory Authorities and their subsidiaries to the Parliament . . .

It is amazing the humbug spoken by members of both Houses of this Parliament about the rights of parliament, the necessity to build their monument on Capital Hill and their places in society. They go around making all these great sorts of speeches, but nobody seems to want to get to the hard nitty-gritty work concerning the accountability to the Parliament of statutory authorities and their subsidiaries. The moment we do, this curse of parliamentary partisan politicking will arise. I hope that this is a matter-which has been gone into in some detail in the report of the Committee-to which the Parliament will address itself, and continue to address itself. I invite honourable senators when they are addressing their party faithfuls, to mention this area instead of doing what we all do-spending all our time telling our party faithful how wonderful we are and how dreadful the other people are. The last matter raised in the proposal is:
the future of Asia Dairy Industries . . .

That must be a matter for Government decision and, finally, parliamentary approval. There is no doubt at all that both Asia Dairy Industries and the Dairy Industry Stabilisation Fund are serious matters for the community to consider. They are matters to which the Government ought to bend its mind and on which the Parliament ought to have an opinion. Therefore, I hope that the Parliament will bend its mind to these things.

The other matter in the report which I regard as serious is whether a statutory authority was indulging in tax evasion. I am not prepared to sit as a judge on that matter. We have been getting lectures in this Parliament from both the Government and the Opposition as to the evils of tax evasion within Australia. It seems that we are getting to the standard by which it is wrong for Australians to do that at home but that it is alright for government-owned corporations to do it abroad. It seems to be wrong for taxpayers to cheat the Australian Government but maybe it is acceptable for government-owned corporations to cheat the revenue raising authorities of friendly countries! I came to the conclusion that this case did not involve tax avoidance; in this case there was a deliberate attempt, in fact a successful attempt until the Committee came on the scene, not to disclose all the true facts to the revenue raising authorities of a friendly country. I would have thought that was a matter to which the Parliament may have directed its attention in the last two days, if we are going to direct so much of our attention to the tax avoiders and evaders of this country.

Senator Chaney is about to direct his attention to those who so arrange their affairs that they get an unfair advantage out of the social security system. I sometimes think that perhaps we ought to clean up our own house-our own statutory corporations-before we go about lecturing the rest of the community. I think it is fair to ask: Where is all the rebate money? I think that is a nice question. So far nobody in the Parliament seems to be fussed about it. I have not noticed those who represent what we might call dairy constituencies making a song and dance in the Parliament about where their constituents' money is. I assume that it is the money of the poor old dairy farmers. It is somebody's money, but nobody seems to care. They think that, after all, it is only a few million dollars abroad, it is in some sort of bank, and why should they really worry?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee says it is not the dairy farmers' money.

—No, that is the difference. We do not know whose money it is. We do not know where it is, who has it, who is entitled to it or what should happen to it. The Parliament does not seem fussed about that. It seems to be more fussed about whether a Minister had a meeting with a chairman of a statutory authority. I must confess that I could not care whether they ever had a meeting. It does not fuss me whether they had a meeting, what they talked about or what they did not talk about. I think some of these other matters I have raised are matters which the Parliament ought to fuss about. It ought to fuss about those matters, not only those concerning the Committee report which I have detailed, but also those matters raised by my friend and colleague, Senator Chaney, in his opening remarks about the standard of conduct of Senate committees. I think we ought to fuss about that. I say again to my friend and colleague, Senator Chaney, that the Cabinet ought to fuss about its standard of behaviour and maybe so should the Parliament. We ought to fuss about how we abuse privilege in this place and in other places, to bring fairness and justice to all sorts of people. I conclude as I started. I did not rise to my feet either to attack the Minister or to defend the report. I rose to beg the Parliament to address itself to the real issues raised by our report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Paragraph (1), leave out sub-paragraphs (a),(b) and (c), insert the following sub-paragraphs:
''(a) the natural values of South West Tasmania to Australia and the world; and

(b) federal responsibility in assisting Tasmania to preserve its wilderness areas of national and international importance, including appropriate financial assistance consistent with the State's development needs and options for the State's energy requirements''.
(2) Paragraph (2), leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
''(2) That the Committee consist of four Senators, as follows:
(a) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.''

This amendment does two things. It changes the wording of the terms of reference originally moved by the Australian Democrats and it reduces the size of the committee. The change in the terms of reference recognises certain facts which I believe should be considered by the Senate before any such inquiry is set up. Part (1) (c) of Senator Chipp's terms of reference states:
the future energy needs of Tasmania and energy options outside South West Tasmania.

The reference to energy options outside south-west Tasmania is interpreted as meaning, and in fact means, that the committee cannot consider the option of a hydro-electricity dam within the South West, including the Gordon-above-Olga proposal of the Tasmanian Government. In other words, the wording as it is implies that this Senate has made up its collective mind that there is no option and that there should be no option for a dam in this area. I suggest that the Senate is not in a position to decide, has not the knowledge to make a judgment about, and has not debated such a proposition. To do so and to put in such a proposition would hamstring the committee of inquiry in its consideration of Tasmania's energy needs. Such a narrow term of reference would ignore the rights of the State and the people of Tasmania to determine their own future, or at least to contribute to the determination of their own future, on this and other energy matters. Quite clearly, if the Federation is to be meaningful, the smaller States need assistance. If decisions are to be made which mean that a State will suffer economically to preserve a wilderness area or an area of special heritage which the rest of Australia wants to preserve then the rest of the country should help financially. Equally, the Parliament and the Senate should satisfy themselves as to the basis of decisions of this type and the need and extent of this type of assistance.

I suggest that the wording of my terms of reference, which I have moved on behalf of the opposition, recognises the values of the South West of Tasmania, recognises the Federal responsibility in relation to the preservation of such areas and recognises the possible need for assistance within the parameters of the State's need for development and the State's energy option. The wording that I have moved does not prejudge the issue and does not imply interference in the State's affairs to the extent that I believe the motion from the Australian Democrats does. For that reason I believe that the amendment to the wording of the Australian Democrat's motion should be supported. I do not think that it detracts at all from the terms of reference and from the ability of the committee to make such an inquiry. It is not restrictive and it does not preclude an option which is considered to be desirable by many people in Tasmania.

Finally, I refer to the proposal to reduce the size of committee to four. I suggest first of all that four is a perfectly satisfactory number. There is precedent for this on select committees, especially committees which have in the past dealt with inquiries in relation to Tasmania. It seems likely that we will have expanded committee activities in this place and will continue to do so. TALK.START.PARA: —I support the appointment of a Senate select committee. South West Tasmania is a national asset and is unique, although it is not unique in being a national asset. The national Parliament is right to be concerned about all national assets and so be concerned about the future of South West Tasmania, just as it would be concerned, and has been concerned, about the future of the Great Barrier Reef or Ayers Rock. We would want to have a say in those matters along with the people and governments of the Northern Territory and Queensland. If there were a proposal to dam the Heads, the entrance to Sydney Harbour, or to knock down the Three Sisters in the Blue Mountains, I would want to be involved. I reject the notion that it is somehow not appropriate for all Australians, through their Federal Parliament, to act to protect their national heritage-both natural and built-just because something is situated within the boundaries of a State. There is a Federal role. In fact, it should be larger and more consistent rather than exist only in an ad hoc way such as proposed in this instance. It would be preferable, instead of there being a select committee, for there to be a public expert inquiry appointed by the Government under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. But the Government has refused to set up such an inquiry, so a Senate select committee is the next best thing and must be resorted to.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is being very coy about its refusal to act. At a later stage I will seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard paragraphs 50 to 58 from the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation on South West Tasmania and Hydro-electric Power Development. I have not had a chance to check with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Chaney) as to whether he will approve of that request. I should like in particular to refer to a couple of sentences from those conclusions. Conclusion No. 53 states:
Proposals likely to have an impact on South West Tasmania are undoubtedly environmental matters of national concern and warrant involvement.
Conclusion No. 56 states:
. . . the Committee believes that only by a Federal inquiry will national considerations and all the alternatives be fully examined.

The Committee recommended that the Commonwealth Government seek advice as to whether the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act applies to the proposed hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania and if there are proposals as defined under the Act that it be invoked. That was a fairly clear recommendation.

The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Wilson, has consistently refused to come to a decision about that recommendation. He is purported as saying in various places, in the House of Representatives on 10 June, and since, I believe, as well as at House of Representatives Estimates Committee hearings, that the Government does not want to make a decision about the appropriateness of that recommendation until the Tasmanian Government and the Tasmanian people make up their minds about the particular proposal involved. In my view that is a totally unsatisfactory excuse. The Minister is saying that the Government does not have a position at all on the general question of the applicability of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act to projects in the States which require loan funds. I presume advice on the question is available from the Attorney-General's Department. The House of Representatives Committee recommended that such advice be sought. If the Government has not yet received the advice, why is there a delay? If it has been received I think the Government ought to table it so that we can all make a judgment about it. In any case, there is no reason, in my view, why the Government cannot make a decision in general terms about the matter, regardless of any specific proposals. It is a general question on which the Government ought to have a position.

I refer quickly to the fact that the Premier of Tasmania, Doug Lowe, has expressed his objections about the proposal to form a select committee. He has said that Tasmanian decisions should be left to Tasmanians and that he does not believe the Federal Government, the Federal Opposition or the Federal Parliament as a whole ought to become involved. He has been critical of the record of 'Canberra' in both environmental and energy matters. I join him in that general criticism, especially as it applies to the present Government. But it needs to be acknowledged that the Federal Labor Government of 1972 to 1975 made giant leaps forward in its attempt to save certain environmentally important areas, in its provision of substantial financial assistance to conservation organisations, in its legislative initiatives, such as the environmental impact statement procedures which I have already referred to, and in many other ways. Even the present Government has a couple of plusses in its actions regarding Fraser Island and whales, to balance against all its negative points.

The basis of my criticism of Canberra would be different from that of the Premier of Tasmania in that I regret the failure of the Federal Parliament to become involved in more issues than it does. Perhaps naturally I am more of an interventionist than the State Premier. I believe that the Federal Parliament ought to interest itself in national issues and that more of the issues currently defined as State matters ought to be made national ones. I am not talking just of Tasmanian issues either. There are too many things about which nothing is done or about which it is said nothing can be done because they are matters for the States. These are the very same things which are crying out for clear overall national policies.

It is disgraceful that energy and resources development are left largely to the States, with the result that there are six, seven or eight different policies, or more accurately six, seven or eight of the same policies wastefully and extravagantly competing with each other. All the States fall over one another to attract, for example, aluminium industries by selling off precious power at cut prices. A national, co-ordinated policy is not just desirable but essential, but it has not happened. Almost without exception energy and resources development plans have an environmental impact. Not only is the whole issue inseparable from environmental considerations but also each project has implications for the local environment.

The conservation issue cannot be ignored, yet so often it is, or at least it is acknowledged but deemed to be subservient to the development plans. Certainly the two cannot be isolated from each other. Hence this inquiry of a Senate select committee will end up dealing not only with the environmental value of south-west Tasmania but also with the plans which threaten it. It is a great pity that all Australia's power development plans cannot be looked at together. However, the Zeidler Committee of Inquiry into Electricity Generating and the Sharing of Power Resources in South-east Australia, is examining the possibility of a south-eastern Australia's power grid, perhaps including a Bass Strait cable. Senator Carrick alluded to this in Question Time yesterday. I think his words were that the report would be available in the immediate weeks ahead. I hope he means that the report will be publicly available and I hope the immediacy will be sufficient for it to be studied not only by this select committee but also in the context of the coming referendum in Tasmania. What that report says may well affect the result of the poll. I support the amendment moved by Senator Grimes. I also now seek leave to incorporate paragraphs 50 to 58 of the House of Representatives committee report.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
6 Conclusions

50. The Committee has not had the time nor has it the resources to examine in detail the complex considerations such as wilderness and conservation values, employment, alternative proposals, future energy requirements and industrial development. Accordingly, the Committee makes no recommendations supporting or opposing further hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania.

51. The Committee believes that many areas of Australia should be preserved in their natural state for the enjoyment of future generations. Any decision to alter areas as significant as South West Tasmania should only be taken after an extensive examination of the alternatives and only when the decision makers are satisfied that there are no feasible and prudent alternatives. It is the Committee's view that this detailed examination has not been undertaken.

52. As outlined earlier in the report, sections of the conservation movement have asked for a Federal Government inquiry into the proposed scheme on the grounds that South West Tasmania is important, not only to Tasmania, but to Australia as a whole. Various State and Commonwealth authorities have recognised the national and international value of the region.

53. The Committee, in its report on legislative and administrative arrangements relating to environmental protection, commented that there will be issues of national importance which warrant Commonwealth involvement. Proposals likely to have an impact on South West Tasmania are undoubtedly environmental matters of national concern and warrant Commonwealth involvement.

54. The Commonwealth is already involved in the region in a number of ways. It provides funds for the South West Tasmania Resources Survey and is committed to assisting the Tasmanian Government in the establishment of parks and reserves. Further, the region has been listed in the Register of the National Estate. In addition, borrowing for the proposal will require the approval of the Australian Loan Council of which the Commonwealth is a member.

55. The Committee notes that the proposal has been examined by the Co-ordinating Committee on Future Power Development and the Tasmanian Government has proposed a hydro-electric development which will leave the Franklin River undammed.
56. Notwithstanding this review and the Tasmanian Government decision the Committee believes that only by a Federal inquiry will national considerations and all the alternatives be fully examined.

57. Mechanisms for this full examination may exist at the Federal level through the public inquiry provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. Accordingly, the Committee recommends that:
the Commonwealth Government seek advice as to whether the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 applies to the proposed hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania; and
if there are proposals as defined under the Act, it be invoked.

58. The Committee supports the continuing Commonwealth financial involvement in the South West Tasmania Resources Survey, the listing of the region in the Register of the National Estate and believes that requests by the Tasmanian Government for assistance in establishing national parks in the South West region should be treated sypathetically by the Commonwealth Government.
August 1980

Some people have expressed reservations that only today a decision was made that there would be a limited number of questions posed at the referendum. We hope that it will be a vehicle for tapping into and marshalling the many points of view which should come forward in an investigation of this matter. SPEECH.PARA: . . . federal responsibility in assisting Tasmania to preserve its wilderness areas of national and international importance, including appropriate financial assistance;

If he has not looked over one he might not know that they have to be about 2,000 megawatts, not kilowatts, as Senator Missen said. People in this country have trouble with kilobucks and megabucks but I never expected them to have trouble with kilowatts and megawatts.
—I have trouble with two and two makes four sometimes, I can assure you.
—Is that millimetres or inches?
—Come on. Let's get on with it.

—There is no rush at all. Let me be the first Liberal senator in this place to say that he is prepared to sit here for as many days as he did last year. I am not in a rush to get out of this place. If any honourable senator is then let him take another look. I do not know about the Democrats, but I am quite prepared to sit here until Christmas time. They may not want to.
—Anything to keep them from their constituents.

—I know their constituents may have a lot of trouble keeping their hands off them. Let us get back to the matter of the atomic power station. The trouble with an atomic power station is that it is about 2,000 megawatts. At the moment in Tasmania about 1,100 megawatts is being produced, which means effectively, in round terms, that there would be three times the power generation in Tasmania than there is at the moment. As an engineer I would love to see a lifeline tying us to Victoria because that would stop us drifting further and further away. I know that some people in the other place would like to see us drift a long way away.
—Geographically.
—Yes.
—Come back to the point.

—The point is that it is not possible to build a power cable that will easily connect Victoria to Tasmania. It would cost $600m, it would be twice as long as any other cable in this world, it would have to be built in situ, and it would take 15 years to build. That is one point. If the honourable senator had been listening he would have remembered that. The next point is that an atomic power station would take 10 years to build and it would generate twice as much power as is presently being generated in Tasmania. We do not really have any alternative to generating more power in Tasmania. I differ here with some of my other colleagues. I believe that we need to build as many efficient dams in Tasmania as will produce the maximum amount of power that will be needed in the next 15 years.
—Stop all this damn nonsense.

—I will not repeat what Senator Rae said; otherwise it will appear twice in Hansard. As I see it, the only alternative is to build the dams. I am in support of an inquiry into Tasmania because some of the inquiries have been very beneficial for us, but I do not think that this one would be beneficial. I do not think it should go ahead until after the referendum in Tasmania, which I am well advised now has only two options, and that is sensible. I believe that the public in its good sense will agree with the stand that I have taken this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.
