SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate calls on the Government to:

(a) transfer the responsibility for administration and funding of the Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS) to a national committee appointed by the Commonwealth Government with respresentation from the community, the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, the Department of Education and, at the State level, from TAFE and Youth and Community Services;

(b) include in the guidelines, in addition to the responsibility for support services now provided by CYSS, the responsibility to seek permanent part-time work for those unemployed people between the ages of 15 and 20 who are unable to find suitable permanent work and who are unable or disinclined to pursue, or temperamentally incapable of pursuing, full time study; and
(c) introduce legislation providing that the entitlement to unemployment benefits of young people employed under this scheme is not affected by the receipt of wages for up to 10 hours work per week.

I will make one or two brief comments about this motion. Firstly, I am aware that there are on both sides senators who are genuinely concerned about the rapidly approaching deadline for the closure of the Community Youth Support Scheme. Time is running out. I suggest that, if an expression of concern cannot be passed in this chamber tonight, any move to save the Community Youth Support Scheme will be too late. It will be two and a half weeks before Parliament reassembles. In the last few weeks those of us who are concerned about the Community Youth Support Scheme have been living in the hope that the Government would make a statement which would hold out some hope that this vital scheme for the support of our unemployed young people could be continued in some guise or other. However, on 15 September, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, in answer to a question from me, stated:

I give the assurance that CYSS will not be replaced by a scheme of another name to be administered by another department. As I have said, the funding for the CYSS program will cease on 31 October as has been announced in the Budget.

On the same day the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) made a similar statement. Nothing has been announced that will encourage one to hold out any hope that the initiative of the Government will be other than was expressed in that very clear statement. In other words, people in the community who are concerned about CYSS, who are trying desperately by all means available to keep this vital scheme going, are rapidly running out of hope. This is the last opportunity that the Parliament has to express to those people the hope that perhaps there will be a change of heart by the Government.

CYSS represents a vital link between the community and unemployed youth in this country. The scheme has had the backing of churches, local councils and concerned citizens generally. Already, on Government instructions, the CYSS programs are being run down. The Commonwealth Employment Service no longer refers young people to CYSS. The organisers of CYSS projects have been told to run down their cash balances. This Parliament will reassemble in two and a half weeks but by then, if we do not pass this motion now, CYSS will be virtually non-existent. A vital link between the community and unemployed, one supported by this Government, will end. This afternoon I heard from Senator Withers probably the most inspiring speech I have heard since I have been a member of the Senate. I will not attempt to quote him but essentially what he said was--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean that you took him at face value?

—I understood Senator Withers to say that it was about time the Parliament stopped point scoring and got on with the business of facing up to the vital problems with which this country was involved. I took his speech at face value; it inspired me. The motion before the Senate is simply a request to the House of Representatives to do something about preserving vital community involvement in assisting our unemployed young people. It is purely a request-nothing more. It seems to me that if the Senate is so hide-bound that senators on both sides of the chamber who are genuinely concerned about preserving this community-based support scheme in some form or other cannot vote other than on strictly party lines, there is something very wrong with our Parliament. We are suggesting purely that a request be made to the House of Representatives. We are approaching the deadline. This is the last opportunity the Parliament will have to make a clear expression to the thousands of people who support CYSS. This is the last opportunity that the Parliament will have to say that there is still some hope that the Government can yet be prevailed upon to change its mind or to come up with some alternative. It is a practical suggestion. It gets away from administration of the support scheme by the rigid control of a government department. It puts the responsibility for administration and funding upon a community-based scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many precedents for this course of action. For instance, each year the Australia Council receives considerable funding from the Government to assist the arts. It is a worthwhile cause and I do not criticise the fact that that is done. What is suggested in the motion represents a similar approach. The present total expenditure on CYSS is $11.5m which is not, I suggest, a large amount to expend in satisfying a vital community need. If we vote down such a request at this time, there can be no doubt in the minds of the thousands of people in the community who try to support unemployed youth that this Government has turned its back on their efforts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I will vote against the motion, I say quite specifically that I applaud the initiative shown-
—That is a fair average quality performance-to support the motion but vote against it.

—I thank Senator Evans for that. He might have listened to me before drawing his conclusion. But we cannot expect every justice to prevail in this chamber. I appreciate what Senator Siddons said about the Community Youth Support Scheme. I too support a continuing existence either of CYSS or of another form of organisation to serve a similar purpose. Senator Siddons in his motion suggested one possibility, one way in which CYSS might be continued. I must say I have received a great number of representations that have urged that it should not cease on 30 October, that it should be continued for a period to develop a desirable situation in the community or, alternatively, that it should not go altogether but should be replaced by another scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret very much that, at the time, the Government proposed the abolition of CYSS because it felt it had weaknesses-undoubtedly there were weaknesses in some of the CYSS groups. I was sorry the Government did not come up with an alternative. I recognise that there is a very considerable demand in the community for a scheme which is something like CYSS. It is all right to say that there ought to be training schemes for the unemployed. That is a very desirable first alternative. At the same time, a number of young people in the community do not find such training schemes of any use to them. They have left school. They have given up that form of training. They need to win back their confidence. They need the assistance of the community in doing so.

I have supported and been interested in CYSS since its foundation. I think that in most places where it has operated it has provided a very useful means whereby such people have been able to feel that they are wanted in society, whereby they have been able to feel, in company with other people, that they can take action to assist themselves in getting jobs.

I believe that in the past some unwise restrictions have been placed on CYSS whereby the objective of seeking jobs has been denied to people. I believe that any new scheme that arises ought to incorporate the practical belief that people ought to be able to use the new skills they acquire in obtaining jobs for themselves. I do not think that the situation is in any way as hopeless as Senator Siddons would lead us to believe. Of course, there has been a great deal of discussion by Government members and a great deal of representation to the Ministry and, in particular, to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) in regard to this matter. The Government is examining the matter at the moment. Its officers are going around various areas and are working out the need that exists and the extent to which employment and training schemes will be needed to help the people who need help.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much time left. It closes on 31 October.

—I will come to that point; I will not ignore it. I think we will find that the Government's analysis of the situation will reveal that there are people who just will not be covered by employment and training schemes and that, therefore, there is a necessity for a substantial scheme which does one very important thing, namely, brings in employers and members of the community who are interested in helping and encourages them to provide equipment, to help to set up projects and to assist in their operation. I believe that that is one of the best things that has resulted from CYSS. That sort of involvement must continue. Sure, the date for CYSS to end is not far away. Time is short, but I believe that the examination of schemes being undertaken at the moment by the Government and its attempts to find out what is happening in the community will lead it to make useful decisions well before that date.

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise that people presently employed as project officers in existing CYSS programs face great difficulty in deciding whether to look for a job elsewhere now or to stay until the deathknock. I urge them to stay, to continue in CYSS. I express the hope that the Government, before the date CYSS is to end, will have worked out a scheme which will pick up all the best aspects of CYSS and will continue the community involvement aspect of CYSS.

For those reasons, I will vote against the motion. I hope that the Government will consider the type of scheme Senator Siddons has put forward in his motion, irrespective of whether we pass or defeat the motion. The great bulk of honourable senators on this side of the chamber are very much of the opinion that there must be a scheme which perpetuates the best elements of CYSS.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has not said that.

—The Minister has not said that. He has indicated that he is making investigations to see what people are not covered by or who are not likely to benefit from the present training schemes. It is on that that I base my belief that the Government will find a means of introducing a scheme which will pick up and continue the most valuable elements of CYSS. For those reasons I will oppose the motion. If I did not believe that the Government would do that I would support the motion, although there might be aspects of it which I did not particularly support. But I believe that the Government recognises that there is a very genuine, widespread demand by society for continued community involvement in the problem of youth unemployment. Because I believe that, I will vote against the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion. One could well have taken most of Senator Missen's speech as being in support of the motion, but that is not uncommon with Senator Missen. Senator Siddons's motion is an attempt to get the Senate to make a statement to the Government and to the other House of this Parliament that, first of all, the Community Youth Support Scheme should be retained and, secondly, that the CYSS guidelines and its structure of control should be changed in certain suggested ways to make it more effective. I might not agree with every word in the motion, but I think it is a reasonable motion and one that deserves support, particularly in the circumstances which Senator Siddons mentioned, namely, that the Parliament is about to rise for a fortnight, the scheme is about to be closed up completely and it is worth supporting.

SPEECH.PARA: On 25 August, soon after we resumed the sittings of the Parliament, I raised a matter of public importance concerning the decision to abolish CYSS, which was announced in the Budget. I did so first of all, because of the obvious support in the community for the continuation of a program like CYSS and, secondly, because of the manner in which the scheme was to be closed down. In the months before the announcement of the cessation of CYSS we heard repeated statements from the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, Mr N. A. Brown, and from other Government supporters that CYSS would continue. Only a week before the Government announcement that CYSS was to be closed down, new project officers were taken on, some of whom had left other jobs to become project officers with CYSS. We had some 800 project officers and more tutors involved in CYSS who had been working in the guaranteed expectation-they had received letters from the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, and had been advised by the Minister and by other Government members-that CYSS would continue.

Senator Missen tells us that he has hope that the Government will reverse its decision. I do not know where he gets that hope from. Since the decision was announced we have heard repeated statements in this House from the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), who is in the House at the moment, that the Budget decision will remain, that it is a firm decision. We have heard repeated statements from Mr Brown, the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, that the Government decision will stand, that there is no intention to change it. The only hopeful statement I have seen reported has in fact been one from the Treasurer, Mr Howard, who said that the Government might look at the number of young people who were not covered by CYSS.

I want to make it quite clear that I am not an uncritical supporter of CYSS as it is and as it has been. Certainly I consider that some CYSS projects have not been efficient and have not been working in a satisfactory way. But the people who have worked in CYSS and who have been involved in committees conducting CYSS projects recognised that. They repeatedly made requests to the Government that their terms of reference and guidelines be broadened to include aspects such as more counselling and the sorts of work training and development programs that Senator Siddons mentioned in the second part of his motion to enable them to do more for the unfortunate group of people in our community who for so long in many cases have been without work. They certainly showed more concern for the young unemployed than did Mr Brown only last week when reportedly he was talking to a 18-year-old girl at the CYSS project in Shepparton and she told him she had been out of work for 18 months. The Minister told her: 'You don't need a job; you need a psychologist'. One wonders what sort of attitude that is from a Minister who is supposed to be concerned for the unemployed in the community. Speeches have been made on this subject in the other place. I refer in particular to one made the other night by Mr Baume, the honourable member for Macarthur, who said that these people do not need assistance of this type; they should be put on welfare because they do not want to work.

The CYSS program, with all its faults, brought concerned people in the community together onto the committees which ran the projects. It brought together project officers and tutors who had a concern to work with individuals who were in the difficult situation of being unemployed at such a young age with not much hope of employment. They demonstrated a concern that there was a need in the community for this sort of work to be done. Bits of propaganda, delivered to us right up to the day after the Budget, pointed out that CYSS was functioning, what it would do and that the Government supported it. The August Youth Affairs newsletter is practically devoted to paeans of praise about the effectiveness of CYSS and the effectiveness of the Office of Youth Affairs in the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. All the indications have been that this project would be continued. Yet in the Budget we are told it has two or three months to run.

Therefore, for all these reasons-because of the manner in which the program has been disbanded, because of the firm statements since the Budget from senior Minisers and Ministers directly involved that the Government would not go back on its decision, and because of the obvious concern in the community-I believe that Senator Siddons' motion deserves support. Senator Siddons suggests a means of administration and funding of CYSS by a national and pretty representative committee. One may quibble about who is on it and who is not but it would be a pretty representaive committee. The honourable senator urges a review and a widening of the guidelines. He urges the formulation of legislation to assist and to encourage young people to take on permanent part time work without having their unemployment benefit removed and thereby building disincentives into the system.

For these reasons I am at a loss to understand why all honourable senators in this place will not support this point of view which can be modified as it is examined by the Government, the House of Representatives or the Senate. But, with the short time available to do something about the matter, the motion is worthy of our support for the moment at least, and I urge honourable senators to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take part in this debate. I have some sympathy with what Senator Siddons is endeavouring to do. I agree with the previous speaker that his approach to this matter is no better than what I or a number of my colleagues have been doing over the last two or three weeks. I have spoken to a number of people who have been involved in the Community Youth Support Scheme. I have listened to the kinds of things that they have been endeavouring to do. I have a great understanding of some of the CYSS organisations that have been doing a tremendous job.

SPEECH.PARA: I have also taken the opportunity, as have colleagues of mine, to make representations to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown). I have spent a great deal of time in very fruitful discussions with the Minister responsible for this area and I am quite confident about what he is endeavouring to do. The Minister has had consultations. Yesterday and today he talked to a number of people who have been involved for some considerable time with CYSS. He is continuing to have those discussions. I am quite confident that the kinds of issues that have been raised here tonight will be taken into consideration by the Minister and the Government. I am confident that a statement will be made very shortly by the Minister that will satisfy all of my worries about the phasing out of CYSS. Rather than CYSS being cut off at a given date, I and a number of my colleagues naturally would have preferred a phasing in of the new scheme that the Minister will come up with as CYSS is phased out.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are that gullible you would fall for a Fraser election promise.

—The honourable senator will have his say. He will have plenty of time in which to stand up and say what he wants to say. He should at least have the courtesy to listen to another person's point of view. It is typical of the honourable senator to want to overtalk someone else and not give him a chance to put his point of view. I am putting forward my point of view. I have had quite lengthy discussions with Senator Siddons on a number of occasions about what he was proposing to do. I said earlier that I have sympathy with what he is endeavouring to do. But in my view his proposition will serve no more purpose than what I and my colleagues have been endeavouring to do over a number of days and weeks by consulting the Minister and the Government on what is the best thing to do for the young people who have been catered for through the CYSS program. The Minister has given me an assurance and I am quite prepared to accept that assurance. I will wait until he makes that announcement to find out exactly what he is going to come up with. I am afraid that under those circumstances I am not able to support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that this Budget item has had more discussion than almost any other matter raised in this years' Budget. The motion that has been brought forward by Senator Siddons calls on the Government to restructure the Community Youth Support Scheme, to form a national committee and to do the other things mentioned in his motion. The decision in the Budget was made against the background of the additional training programs and the additional opportunities for training that were provided in the Budget funding for young people. The Government feels that young people would be better served by employment and training programs that would lead them into opportunities for employment. But, as we have seen over the last few weeks when we have been discussing these matters, there is a recognition in the community of the work that has been done through the CYSS programs for those young people who may not be able to involve themselves in training programs, education programs or any of the other programs that provide opportunities for them. It seems to me that the community has developed a discussion about CYSS that has brought out some of the things that were said by Senator Bonner, Senator Grimes, Senator Missen and Senator Siddons who introduced this motion. There has been a degree of community involvement which needs to be recognised for the value and the extra dimension it brings to a program of this sort.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion moved by Senator Siddons speaks of the administration of CYSS being transferred to a national committee. The honourable senator set out in the first paragraph of his motion how that body should be styled. We ought to remember that CYSS has been administered by State committees which consist of two represenatives from the community, a representative of the Commonwealth Department of Employment and Youth Affairs and a representative of the relevant State department. Usually the State department is the department responsible for youth affairs. The school to work transition program is also administered by State committees consisting of representatives of Federal and State departments of labour and education, including the technical and further education authorities.

In the last couple of weeks I have answered a number of questions in regard to this program on behalf of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown). I have said on a number of occasions that at present the Government is considering the information that is coming through to the Minister from the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs as the result of the decision in the Budget to terminate at 31 October CYSS as it presently exists. We have said that as a result of that information, if there are gaps in the range of programs, consideration will be given to taking special action to meet the needs of young people who are not catered for in the training, education and employment programs. As I said quite recently, and as the Minister has said, the matter is being investigated by Commonwealth Employment Service officers. If there are people who, for reasons of geographical location or lack of attitude, aptitude or ability, cannot undertake further educational training, the Government will consider that and the Minister, I feel, will make whatever appropriate announcement needs to be made.

The establishment of a national committee suggested by Senator Siddons in his motion would need to be considered in light of the fact that even if a national committee were formed to oversee the CYSS program the administration and funding of it must remain within a specified portfolio with a specified department being responsible. The formation of a national committee would not solve some of the difficulties that may have existed in some of the programs, as has been mentioned by some honourable senators. I think it was Senator Grimes who said that he is not uncritical of some CYSS programs as they have existed in the past. All a national committee could do would be to make recommendations to the appropriate Minister whose responsibility it would be to administer a program such as that envisaged by Senator Siddons. In other words, that could even complicate the administration of the program without necessarily addressing the main issue, and that is to make available to young people opportunities for education, training and employment.

The second part of the motion deals with the inclusion in the guidelines of some further matters. With regard to that part of the motion I say simply that part time vacancies may be lodged with the Commonwealth Employment Service. There is really no need to duplicate the services provided by the Commonwealth Employment Service through a new CYSS network. The CYSS projects are already able to undertake incidental placements including part time work. Some CYSS projects, especially those in the country areas, are now doing this. These placements are, however, only additional to their basic functions. If the Government believes as a result of its current investigations that there is a need for an enhanced service of this type, consideration will be given to that matter. In the meantime, anybody who wishes to lodge part time vacancies for young people should do so through the comprehensive Commonwealth Employment Service network which already exists and which is decentralised throughout Australia.

The third section of the motion refers to introducing legislation to vary entitlement for unemployment benefit. In that connection I say that the income test provisions for unemployment benefit were changed in the Budget of last year. Under those changes young people may now earn up to $40 a week before unemployment benefit expires. They lose 50c of their unemployment benefit for every dollar over $3 earned in a week. Those changes were made in order to increase the incentives for young people on unemployment benefit to undertake part time work, which is the matter addressed in that third part of the motion before us. In other words, again it is not necessary to have a CYSS project to increase this incentive.

In any event, it could be unfair to those young people who undertake part time work on their own accord to be disadvantaged by a more severe income test than the test given to those who obtain their work through a CYSS project. A young person doing part time work for 10 hours a week could expect to earn, say, $25. If this person were in receipt of unemployment benefit he would lose $11 of that benefit, making the total income $50 a week; that is, $25 of earned income plus $25 of unemployment benefit. It would be difficult to justify the exemption of certain income for income test purposes for only one group of people who were involved in a particular program, as is envisaged in this motion.

As I have said, the Minister is presently giving a great deal of time to consultation on and consideration of the matters being investigated by the Commonwealth Employment Service. As soon as the investigation has been undertaken and completed to his satisfaction he will be in a position to address the needs of those young people who are not catered for in the programs for which ongoing funding has been provided in the Budget. I feel sure that he will make appropriate statements dealing with those matters. For these reasons the Government is not able to support the motion moved by Senator Siddons, although we recognise the sincerity with which he has brought forward these matters. I thank the Senate for the way in which they have been discussed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too place on record my appreciation of Senator Siddons bringing this matter before the Senate. However, I wish to point out the very evident fact that, firstly, we in the Senate-each one of us-had nothing to do with the abolition of the Community Youth Support Scheme. Its abolition came as a complete surprise to us as it did to anyone else. Secondly, even if we were to adopt the proposal now before us it is quite clear that that would not in any shape or form alter the decision made by the Government in respect of CYSS. Were I Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs I would have sorted out those CYSS programs which were beneficial to the youth of this country from those programs which were and are prejudicial to the youth of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it has been said on both sides of this Parliament, in both this chamber and the House of Representatives, that there is not unqualified support for all of the CYSS programs. My view is that rather than abolish the CYSS programs, the Minister should have grasped the nettle and abolished those programs which were not doing any good for the youth of this country and allowed those which were beneficial to operate. However, no matter what we do tonight the Government is intent on proceeding to abolish CYSS. On no fewer than three occasions I have had the opportunity of discussing with the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) the issues involved in this matter. I-along with Senator Siddons, Senator Bonner and others in this chamber-am concerned at the prospect of what will happen to those persons who are temperamentally incapable of pursuing full time work at this stage. I am concerned particularly for those people in the regional districts. I believe the Minister has made it clear that following the consultations now taking place between departmental officials and people in CYSS programs, on his receiving those reports he will make an announcement which will address this matter.

I can state only that my view is the same as that of Senator Bonner. He presented the case more eloquently than I could and I support what he said. At this time I am prepared to allow the Minister the opportunity, once these investigations have been made, to make his statement. After that it may well be that this chamber and the House of Representatives will need to consider that statement and in light of it determine their positions. I believe the motion is premature at this time. I believe that carrying this motion may give false hope to those involved in the program that it is going to continue when, no matter what we say in the Senate, it will not continue. Therefore, at this stage I am not prepared to support the proposition.
Question put.
That the motion (Senator Siddon's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate declares that any decision by the Senate to make requests to the House of Representatives for amendment of the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A-9A) 1981 does not indicate that the Senate considers that all of the provisions of those Bills are properly included in Bills imposing taxation.

The purpose of this motion is twofold. Firstly, its adoption by the Senate will indicate quite clearly and unambiguously to the House of Representatives that, even though the Senate might convey to the House certain requests on these Bills, such action does not preclude any later action which the Senate may be forced to take in relation to those features of the Bills which the Senate may consider objectionable. Secondly, the motion before the Chair is intended to focus particular attention on the form of drafting of these Bills, in particular Bills 1A to 9A, so it is perfectly clear to all concerned that even at this early stage of consideration of the Bills the Senate is suspicious that an unprecedented form of drafting has been deliberately employed by the Government for devious and unscrupulous purposes in an attempt to circumscribe the Senate in the proper exercise of its power.

Honourable senators no doubt will be aware, since the discussion of Standing Orders has been the order of the day, that our Standing Orders contain a provision for a motion called 'the previous question', which provision I understand has never been used previously. It is a means of avoiding a vote on a motion which is immediately before the Chair. In other words, it really takes the form that the question be not now put. I have noted that this procedure is available in a number of union rules, and it is available to the Senate. In a sense, what I am doing tonight is intended to forestall the presentation in the media or in the corridors of this Parliament of what could be described loosely as 'the after question'. My motion is framed so as to prevent the suggestion being made, after the transmission of requests to the House of Representatives, that the Senate, by confining itself to those requests, thereby relinquishes its right to take further action on these sales tax Bills which it considers necessary to take. Such action includes my suggestion of a division of the Bills pursuant to Standing Order 330 or the other avenue mentioned in my letter to the party leaders dated 4 September this year, namely, action via the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act.

Honourable senators will recognise that adoption of my motion will tend to prompt agreement by the House of Representatives to any request which a majority of the Senate may make about the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A-9A) in the Committee of the Whole. In effect we will be saying this to the House of Representatives: 'The Senate is offering the House of Representatives this immediate opportunity to remove the iniquitous features of these Bills, that is, those features which impose a sales tax on previously exempted items, necessities of life, as they have been described, clothing, footwear, educational books and the like, but let it be clearly understood by the House of Representatives that if it rejects these requests then the Senate may very well take certain other action.' This will add strength to any request which we adopt in the committee debate which will follow.

Surely it is not too strong for me to use the words 'unprecedented', 'devious' and 'unscrupulous' to describe the drafting of these Sales Tax Amendment Bills (No. 1A-9A). The way that these Bills have been drafted comes very close to re-instating a practice which brought contempt to the Parliament in Great Britain 300 years ago. In the 17th century, and earlier, the House of Commons deliberately included in Supply Bills and Bills of Aid matters which were foreign to the main purposes of those Bills. This practice was described as tacking. The whole purpose was to make those Bills non-amendable because of their money character. The same tactic has been applied by the Government on this occasion so as to suggest to certain honourable senators that the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (No. 1A-9A) are non-amendable. Unless the Senate signals its recognition of the Government's endorsement of that tactic, we will be conceding grounds of power which we rightly possess under the Constitution.

There are some among this Government who would emphatically support the words of the late Harold Holt in 1967, two days before the Senate legitimately negated the second reading of the Post and Telegraph Bill, when he declared that it was allegedly 'a firmly established principle' that a House of review-that is the Senate-'should not reject the financial decisions of the popular House'. He used that term to describe the House of Representatives. I am indebted to an article in the journal The Table by our former Clerk, Mr Roy Bullock, about those events in 1967. But let us pause for a moment and consider the implications of Mr Holt's words 'the financial decisions'. He apparently did not even concede the powers given to the Senate in the Constitution. Quite clearly the Senate has those powers to reject those Bills. In respect of proposed laws, it does have the power to proceed in accordance with its Standing Orders.

Tacking is not something that is done only on the River Derwent on a Saturday afternoon, or even on the Sydney Harbour; it is something which an unscrupulous government does so as to place its actions above parliamentary amendment. In this instance the Government might not have made itself open to a formal breach under section 53 of the Constitution. It is too clever by half. I have a secret admiration for the way in which the Government has drafted these pieces of legislation. This legislation has been drafted in an unprecedented fashion. This fashion has never been used in the 51 years in which the principal Act has existed. It has never been done before. Why has it been done? What has occurred on this occasion which has not occurred previously is that the Government has incorporated machinery provisions with the provisions of a tax. I seek leave to table the various sales tax amendment Acts and sales tax Acts over the last 51 years. I defy any honourable senator to go through all of these Acts and find where the Government previously has done what it proposes to do on this occasion.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —What it has done is best illustrated by asking four simple questions. Firstly, is a Bill to amend the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act a Bill which the Senate may amend? Secondly, are Bills to amend the Sales Tax Assessment Acts Bills which the Senate may amend? Thirdly, does proposed new section 6 in clause 3 of each of the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A-9A) modify each of the Acts referred to in the preceding two questions? Fourthly, have any Acts amending the Sales Tax Acts (Nos 1-9) contained provisions modifying the Sales Tax Assessment Acts or the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Acts? The answer to all of those questions is in the negative. But the answer to the question 'Has the Government on this occasion included in the one Bill before the Parliament provisions to amend the Sales Tax Assessment Act and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act', is yes.

SPEECH.PARA: So here we have a situation in which the Government, for the first time in 51 years, has proposed a set of Bills which is unique and designed to hoodwink the Senate into the belief that they are non-amendable. I point out to the Senate that I for one and, I believe, the majority of the Senate will not go along with that tactic that has been used by the Government. Why has it used this unprecedented tactic on this sole occasion in the last 51 years? It has done it precisely for the same reason that the despicable practice of tacking was employed 300 years ago, namely, to clothe the proposed laws in a non-amendable garb. There is no doubt about it, these Bills have been imperfectly drafted. The imposition of the tax should have been separate from the machinery provisions, as has been the case over the last 51 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened before then, before the 51 years?

—My friend Senator Missen asks what happened before 51 years ago. That was in 1930. Nothing happened before then because there was no sales tax. I am talking about history. The first sales tax Bill was introduced 51 years ago. Does the honourable senator want me to go further back than that?
—No, that will do.

—Okay. I am talking about the history of sales tax provisions. If this is the level of the information of the Government on this very important question then I despair of the Government and the legal eagles in it. If we concede that these Bills have been properly drafted on this occasion, what wider provisions are likely to be included in all future taxation Bills to come before the Senate? That is the question to which we ought to address our minds. I suggest that the limits to the boundaries of such Bills will never be constrained by the determination of the Government to thwart the Senate and the ingenuity of skilled draftsmen who are at the disposal of the Government. I do not blame the skilled draftsmen on this occasion. They act under instructions. But when the Archives records are available in 30 years I believe there will be very little written evidence as to the instruction given by the Government on this occasion to those skilled draftsmen.

SPEECH.PARA: If any honourable senator has any doubt about the unknown possibilities which lay ahead of them, they should consider the case in 1943, which was cited by Mr Odgers, in which the government of that day linked the proclamation of an income tax Bill with the operation of the National Welfare Fund Act. Who in the Senate believes that the Government, if it gets away scot-free on this occasion, will not turn to manoeuvres such as those which were employed in 1943 and which, incidentally, were not determined but were by-passed after a conference between the two Houses. Just imagine the different forms of siamese twins which could emerge from linking tax Bills to non-tax Bills.

In the final analysis the limitations of section 53 of the Constitution of Australia are for the Senate itself to interpret and for the two Houses of Parliament to determine. I re-emphasise that point, Mr President. You were not in the chair when we were discussing this matter on a previous occasion. We are dealing with proposed laws. Those proposed laws and our actions in relation thereto are not subject to any outside decision by any court in this land. They are proposed laws. Whatever legal argument the Government may advance, subsequent to my address tonight, to defend its current action, it cannot disguise the fact that for 51 years governments of all kinds have fastidiously separated machinery provisions from the imposition of sales tax itself. The adoption of my motion must lead to a more serious consideration by the House of Representatives of the requests which, I understand, will attract the majority of support on the balance of probabilities in the Committee of the Whole. In effect, if we accept my motion, we shall warn the House of Representatives, in a polite but firm manner, that its agreement to the requests now might prove to be the least embarrassing course open to it. At the same time the Senate will be conveying to the Government that there is a line of demarcation between what is right and proper and what is clever and unscrupulous. It will also be an invitation to the Government to move from the course it has set in the twentieth century towards the reimposition of tactics which were abandoned in their most distasteful form almost 300 years ago.

Finally, lest the Government, as part of its justification of or opposition to my motion, relies on the proposition that the Senate can make requests only in respect of Bills which it may not amend pursuant to section 53 of the Constitution, I draw the Government's attention to the word 'suggest' in section 57 of the Constitution. Quite clearly, the Senate has the power to make suggestions to the House of Representatives in respect of any Bill, whether or not it is a money Bill. Lest the Government hangs its hat on the proposition that a suggestion is not a request, let me remind you, Mr President, and the Senate of what I said when I moved for the suspension of Standing Orders. It is inconceivable that anyone could sustain a pro- position that a suggestion made by this place is not in fact a request to the House of Representatives if it is attached to the Bills.

I remind the Senate of what I said previously in the hope that the Government does not take this track. To make a suggestion to a Bill is not simply a matter of passing a motion and put it in a suggestion box in the middle of King's Hall which once a week is cleared by the Joint House Department and the honourable senator making the suggestion receiving some sort of reward. A suggestion is in fact what it is designed to be in section 57-a legitimate tactic by this House to suggest amendments to the House of Representatives. In all of the circumstances I urge the Senate to support the motion that the Senate, in making requests to the House of Representatives, does not necessarily consider that the Bills which are currently before us-namely, the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A-9A)-are properly drafted. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The opinion read as follows-
SALES TAX AMENDMENT BILLS NOS. 1A TO 9A WHETHER CONSISTENT WITH SECTION 55 OF THE CONSTITUTION
Opinion

My opinion has been sought on the following question: ''Are any of the provisions that are proposed to be inserted (by the Sales Tax Amendment Bills Nos. 1A to 9A) in the Sales Tax Act (No. 1) 1930 and other Sales Tax Acts provisions that, by reason of the Constitution, should not be included in any 'law imposing taxation'?''

2. For clarity's sake I shall say something of the statutory background against which the Bills must be understood. I shall treat the Sales Tax Act No. 1 as the type for each Sales Tax Act and the No. 1 Assessment Act as the type for the various Assessment Acts.
Sales Tax Act (No. 1) 3. Section 2 provides that the No. 1 Assessment Act shall be incorporated and read as one with the Tax Act.

4. Section 3 imposes tax at the rates specified in section 4 upon the sale value of goods manufactured in Australia by a taxpayer (an expression defined in section 3(1) of the Assessment Act) and, on or after 16 August 1978, sold by him or treated by him as stock for sale by retail or applied to his own use.

5. The various rates of tax imposed are described in section 4 by reference to goods covered by Schedules to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act and by reference to a further class defined as those not covered by the Second, Third, Fourth or Fifth Schedules to that Act and on the sale value of which the Exemptions and Classifications Act does not provide that sales tax imposed by the Sales Tax Act (No. 1) shall not be paid.

6. The Sales Tax Act (No. 2) follows the same scheme for imposing tax, but, because laws imposing taxation, except those imposing duties of customs or excise must deal with one subject of taxation only (section 55 of the Constitution, second paragraph), section 3 imposes tax at the rates specified in section 4 upon the sale value of goods manufactured in Australia and, on or after 16 August 1978, sold by a taxpayer who purchases them from the manufacturer.

7. Section 2 of each of the Tax Acts (Nos. 1 to 9) incorporates the corresponding Assessment Act and describes the goods the subject of the tax by reference either solely or partly to Schedules to the Exemptions and Classification Act.

Assessment Acts 8. The Assessment Acts contain provisions necessary to work out the scheme of imposition and the procedures essential to the determination and recovery of the tax imposed by the Tax Acts. They contain, in other words, some provisions dealing with the imposition of tax additional to those contained in the Tax Act and others relating only to its recovery.

Exemptions and Classifications Act 9. The Tax Acts are in much the same general form now as on their introduction in 1930. Then as now the relevant Assessment Act was incorporated: Each Act defined one subject of taxation; but, due to the passing in 1935 of the Exemptions Act and of the Exemptions and Classifications Act in 1940 and their subsequent amendment, the goods upon the sale value of which the tax was imposed came mostly to be described by reference to the Schedules of that Act.

10. Thus, essential to the imposition of these taxes was a statement of the transactions attracting tax, the goods the subject of the transactions, the persons participating in them and the rates of tax. The Assessment Acts contained provisions dealing with the imposition of tax necessary to an understanding of the Tax Acts as well as other provisions, and the Schedules to the Exemptions and Classification Act described goods subject to and exempt from tax. None of these Acts impose taxation.
The Bills 11. Again I shall treat the Bill (No. 1A) 1981 as the type and describe it in language apt to its operation if passed.

12. Clause 3 repeals sections 3 and 4 of the No. 1 Tax Act, that is, the provisions which describe the transactions upon which tax is imposed (part of the subject of taxation) and that which specified the rates of tax varying according to which Schedule of the Exemptions and Classifications Act described the relevant goods and in paragraph (d) defining a class by reference to the fact that they do not appear in the nominated schedules and are not otherwise exempt by the Exemptions and Classifications Act.
13. It proposes in their stead a new section 3 imposing as from 1 January 1982 tax upon the sale value of goods to which the new section 4 will apply and then describes the transactions.

14. The new section 4 declares the rates of tax again in part by reference to goods covered by the Second, Third, Fourth and Fifth Schedule to the Classifications and Exemptions Act and in part by reference to all goods except those to which section 5 of that Act applies and those which that Act says are goods upon the sale value of which no tax is payable although section 5 does not apply to them.

15. The new section 5 also imposes tax as from 1 January 1982 at 2.5% upon the same subject of tax mentioned in the new section 3, but only by reference to transactions in such of those goods as are described in nominated items in the First Schedule to the Exemptions and Classifications Act and those which were immediately before 1 January 1982 exempt because goods of a kind mentioned in paragraph 5 (2) (a) were so exempt.

16. The new section 6 (a), bearing in mind that section 2 of the No. 1 Act (which the Bill seeks to amend) provides that the No. 1 Assessment Act shall be incorporated and read as one with the No. 1 Tax Act, says (and I state the substance) that it shall be so read as if it had no section 20 for the purpose only of reading it with the proposed new section 5, but not with the new sections 3 or 4. The new section 6 (b) says that the Exemptions and Classifications Act is to be read for the purpose of the new section 5 as if the items referred to in the new sub-section 5 (2) were not there, but it is not to be so read for the purposes of reading it with the new sections 3 and 4.
17. Clause 4 continues in existence the repealed provisions as tax imposing provisions in relation to the period up to 1 January 1982.
18. The remaining Bills do not require separate examination.

19. Section 55 of the Constitution requires that laws imposing taxation shall deal only with the imposition of taxation. Such laws must deal only with one subject of taxation except that laws imposing duties of customs and excise may deal with more than one subject of taxation provided they deal only with duties of customs and excise respectively.
20. I shall deal first with the question whether the Bills deal with more than one subject of taxation.

21. What constitutes a subject of taxation is ''based on common understanding and general conceptions, rather than on any analytical or logical classification'': Resch v. Federal Commissioner of Taxation (1942) 55 CLR 198 at p. 223 per Dixon J. I should think it is clear beyond reasonable dispute that each of the Bills deals and only deals with one subject of taxation to the same degree and for the same reasons as have the corresponding Tax Acts since 1930. Each selects one transaction or event in relation to defined dealings in goods by defined persons.

22. Do any of the Bills deal with any matter other than the imposition of taxation? The incorporation of the Assessment Act in the Tax Acts by section 2 operates only for purposes of reference. Those Acts are not thereby to be treated as if they dealt with any matter other than the imposition of taxation. Such has been the law since 1911: Osborne v. Commonwealth (1911) 12 CLR 321; Federal Commissioner of Taxation v. Munro (1926) 38 CLR 153 at pp. 185, 192-193, 208-210, 215-216, 218. This is so although some provisions of the Assessment Acts deal with the imposition of tax and others deal with additional matters: Re Dymond 101 CLR 11 at pp. 20-21 and 23-25.

23. If the Assessment Acts may be incorporated for reference purposes without infringing section 55, it necessarily follows that a provision such as the new section 6 (a) of the Bills does not infringe the section. Its sole purpose is to indicate the extent of the reference. The provision does not, of course, amend the Assessment Act. It operates for the purposes of one proposed section only and thus assumes that the Assessment Act continues unaffected not only for other proposed sections, but for all other purposes. Even it its effect was to amend the Assessment Act, it would do so to explain the nature of the tax imposed, that is, it would impose or deal with the imposition of taxation.

24. As I have earlier indicated, tax has been for many years imposed by reference to the Schedules to the Exemptions and Classifications Act. In that way the Tax Exemptions and Classifications Act. In that way the Tax Acts describe the goods, dealings in which are made the occasion of imposition of tax. The proposed section 6 (b) indicates the extent to which the Exemption and Classification Act is to be referred to for the purposes of one new section only and like the proposed section 6 (a) does not amend it. The authorities I have earlier referred to show that this provision like the proposed section 6 (a) does not infringe section 55.

25. It should be remembered that the Bills before the Senate do not contain provisions incorporating the Assessment Acts. No ground save the references to specific provisions of the Assessment and Exemptions and Classification Acts exists for saying they deal with matters other than the imposition of tax. Once it is realised that the Assessment Acts contain provisions which may appear in the Tax Acts (as Re Dymond (supra) establishes), then that reference cannot support the proposition that thereby the Acts infringe Section 55. Both history and common sense are clearly opposed to it.
26. I answer the question, no.
M. H. BYERS Solicitor-General 17 September 1981

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. We must turn to section 55 of the Constitution in order to determine whether the provisions in the Bills--
—Can I have a copy of that opinion as I have a right of reply?

—I do not have to clear things before I seek leave. I distributed copies of the opinion to the of Opposition parties and Senator Harradine earlier this evening. I turn to section 55 of the Constitution. Mr Byers's opinion deals at length with the Bills in a detailed form and the provisions of section 55 of the Constitution. The clauses of the Bills regarded by Senator Harradine as infringing the Constitution are those dealing with the modification to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act and the Sales Tax Assessment Acts. It appears that Senator Harradine does not fully appreciate the scope of section 55 of the Constitution. Let me put it as simply as I can: A law imposing taxation can contain two types of provisions without infringing section 55. A law imposing taxation can contain provisions, firstly, which actually impose taxation and, secondly, which deal with the imposition of taxation. When so combined the proposed law retains its character as a law imposing taxation and, by virtue of section 53 of the Constitution, cannot be amended by the Senate. As is made clear in the Solicitor-General's opinion that I have incorporated in Hansard, there is clear and unequivocal High Court authority for these propositions. I refer to the case of Dymond which was dealt with in the previous opinion of Mr Byers, a copy of which some honourable senators would have received. To give the Senate an idea of the type of provisions which can be included in a law imposing taxation without infringing section 55 I shall quote from the judgment of Mr Justice Fullagar in the case of Dymond. I might say that the other justices of the High Court, including Sir Owen Dixon, agreed with him. The judgment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It does not mean that an Act imposing taxation can do no more than say 'An income tax is imposed at the following rates', and then specify the rates. It would not be 'dealing with' anything other than the imposition of taxation if it prescribed the persons who were to pay the tax and the classes of income in respect of which they were to be taxed. It may very well be that an Act imposing an income tax could, without offending against s. 55, contain all or most of the provisions in fact contained in Pt. III of the Income Tax and Social Services Contribution Assessment Act, which is headed 'Liability to Taxation' (now Part III of the Income Tax Assessment Act). Such provisions do not impose taxation, but they deal with the imposition of taxation, because the specification of the persons who are to be liable to taxation and the definition of their liability is part of the denotation of the term 'imposition of taxation'.

Thus, for Senator Harradine's assertion that the provision of the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A-9A) 1981 modifying the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act and the Sales Tax Assessment Act infringe section 55 to be correct, these provisions must neither impose taxation nor deal with the imposition of taxation.

I will deal with the modifications to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act and the Assessment Act separately. With reference to the exemptions and classifications Act, the only difference of legal opinion to date, or at least until Senator Harradine's contribution, is on whether that Act imposed taxation. After all, a Bill to remove an exemption would automatically result in liability to sales tax in respect of the relevant goods under Sales Tax Acts (Nos 1-9) or deal with the imposition of taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are amendable by the Senate.

—That is what we are debating. To my knowledge, never before has the argument been raised that the exemptions and classifications Act or any amendments or modifications thereto neither imposed nor dealt with the imposition of taxation. Indeed, the eminent constitutional lawyer Professor Lane in his book entitled The Australian Federal System at pages 394 and 395 and citing re Dymond as authority lists what he considers to be provisions dealing with the imposition of taxation. In that list he expressly includes 'provisions by which liability to tax is ascertained, such as those dealing with deductions, rebates and exemptions'.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the proposed section 6 (b) to be inserted in each Sales Tax Act by Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A-9A), the Senate should understand that that paragraph provides for the exemptions and classifications Act to have effect as if presently exempted items referred to in proposed section 5 (2) were omitted from the exemptions and classifications Act. This paragraph is a necessary adjunct to the imposition of sales tax on those items referred to in proposed section 5 (2). Clearly, proposed section 6 (b) is, at the very least, a law dealing with the imposition of taxation.

As to the modification to the Sales Tax Assessment Acts by proposed section 6 (a), I draw the Senate's attention to the Solicitor-General's opinion at the foot of page 2 where he says that 'they' that is, the assessment Acts-'contain some provisions dealing with the imposition of taxation additional to those contained in the Tax Act'. I refer the Senate further to that opinion.

This brings me to the final point of the argument that I wish to present to the Senate this evening. Senator Harradine has accused the Government of acting improperly when it combined the amendment and modifications to the Sales Tax Act, the Sales Tax Assessment Act and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act in one Bill. As I have said, whether the Government is entitled to do that depends in the end on section 55 of the Constitution. The decisions of a government and this Parliament ultimately will be determined by the High Court. I have referred to a decision of the High Court, the leading High Court authority on the subject in Re Dymond. The Government maintains that the Bills as drafted satisfy the requirements of that High Court decision and of section 55 of the Constitution. But it raises a point-a fundamental point which honourable senators ought to observe and one which, I think, Senator Harradine in his argument seems to have overlooked-which is fundamental to our Constitution. The point is that the Government, being the group having the majority in the House of Representatives, and the Government alone, is responsible for the content and form of laws imposing and dealing with the imposition of taxation. The Senate can reject them. There is no doubt about that whatever but, subject to the Constitution and subject to the High Court, it is for the government of the day to determine what should be in money Bills that are to be introduced-and can be introduced only into the House of Representatives and furthermore can be introduced into the House of Representatives only on the motion of the Executive. Those are absolutely fundamental points of our Constitution. The Government is entitled to present its money Bills in the form in which it chooses. To reinforce this point, and to conclude my remarks in relation to this motion, I would like to quote from another constitutinal text of Lumb and Ryan. The learned authors stated:

The formulation of the revenue requirements for the financial year are to be determined by the government of the day, and the Bills piloted through the House of Representatives by the Treasurer, who will inevitably be a member of the Lower House. It is clear, therefore, that it was not to be the task of the Senate to take the initiative in formulating such basic proposals of government.

Mr President, the motion before us tonight which has been moved by Senator Harradine strikes at the very foundation and the provisions of our Constitution in relation to this vital aspect of the financial proposals for the year which are the responsibility of the Government to introduce into and pass through the House of Representatives. For those reasons the Government will oppose strongly the motion that has been moved by Senator Harradine.

The burden of the Attorney-General's speech was to deal with laws already enacted by the Parliament; that is to say, dealing with section 55 of the Constitution. Of course, section 55 of the Constitution is clear. It deals with legislation already enacted by the Parliament and given royal assent. It is certainly for the High Court to determine whether those laws are valid but we are not dealing with that question at all; we are dealing with proposed laws. We are dealing with laws proposed by the Government, formulated by the Government and presented by the Government in a manner in which it has never before presented them to the Parliament. That is the one thing to which the Attorney-General has not addressed his mind.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask you, Mr President, and the rest of the Senate: Has the Attorney-General explained to the Senate why on this sole occasion the Government has decided to incorporate in the one Bill the provisions that it has incorporated? The Attorney-General's sole defence for that is to allege that the Government-I hope I quote the Attorney-General correctly-is responsible for what laws will come before the Parliament and in what form they will come. That is not contested in regard to money Bills. Under section 53 of the Constitution, the Senate does not have the power to formulate and initiate laws relating to money Bills. Of course, it is for the Government and the House of Representatives to do that. In those circumstances the Government by definition must determine the form in which money Bills are presented to the Parliament. So what? If the House of Representatives alone has the power to initiate money Bills, of course the Government alone has the power to determine in what form those money Bills will be presented to this Parliament. That begs the question entirely.

We are saying that when those proposed laws come before the Parliament, we as a Senate have the responsibility and the right to consider the appropriateness of their formulation. We have the responsibility to consider whether there is some subterfuge, exercised by the Government, designed to thwart the power of the Senate. That is what we are talking about. We are not talking about the gobbledegook that has been outlined by the Attorney-General and, with respect, by the Solicitor-General, It is not gobbledegook if we are talking about section 55 of the Constitution. What the Solicitor-General and the Attorney-General have said is undeniably correct. There is no question at all of that, but they are not addressing themselves to the crux of the matter: Has the Government on this unique occasion presented the Senate with a set of Bills so as to thwart the Senate in the proper exercise of its powers?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Of course, the answer is yes. It has done so, and it has done so on this occasion for the first time in the history of sales tax legislation. I submit that all the statements of the Attorney-General have been directed to section 55 of the Constitution, which deals with laws already enacted, and to the power of the High Court, for example, to determine whether those laws are valid. What we are dealing with tonight is a proposition as to whether we as a Senate, an integral part of the legislative power which is enshrined in section 1 of the Constitution, have the right to determine our own affairs, to determine whether those sales tax Bills are properly formulated and whether they seek to deny and thwart our power. That is the simple question. In my motion I am not asking honourable senators necessarily to make a judgment on that matter but simply to say that when requests are made to amend Bills 1A to 9A we are not thereby denying ourselves the right ultimately to consider the legislation and to divide it in accordance with Standing Order 330, if that is so determined at that stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In respect of all nine Bills I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 2, clause 3, proposed new section 5, sub-section (2), paragraph (a), leave out ''51''.

The intention of this request to the House of Representatives is to exempt from the 2 1/2 per cent proposed sales tax books and other information publications. Senator Harradine referred earlier to a number of nefarious dealings undertaken by a British government hundreds of years ago. I would like to refer briefly to another tax measure that was undertaken and later dropped. I refer to the tax on windows. Of course, that tax had the effect of blocking the light. I contend that a tax on knowledge of the sort envisaged in the taxing of books and other information would be, metaphorically, a tax on the light that those items afford the Australian public. It is an absurd tax to impose and one to which we are opposed. Like other honourable senators, I have been inundated with requests from organisations that we oppose the proposed 2 1/2 per cent sales tax. I quote from one of those letters in order to give their essence:

This proposed tax is in reality a tax on the free flow of information and a tax on education. There is a real danger too that this tax will be increased in future years much in the same way as other sales tax provisions have been increased in the 1981 Budget. Furthermore, a sales tax of this nature could potentially be used to carry out censorship.

I remind honourable senators of a comment that I made on 9 September in a second reading speech on these sales tax amendment Bills. In referring to the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, I made the point that we intended to oppose the imposition of sales tax on the necessities of life-the sorts of things covered by Articles 25 and 26 of the Declaration. Specifically in relation to this amendment, I refer honourable senators to the first sentence of item 1 of Article 26, which states that everyone has the right to education. It must be patently apparent to everybody in this chamber that access to education, either formally through the primary or secondary schools, or the tertiary system, or informally through access to general information, will be hindered if people find it beyond their means to acquire that information. The Australian Democrats feel strongly that the House of Representatives should be petitioned, and petitioned constantly, to remove item 51 from clause 3, proposed new section 5, sub-section 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter the debate on the sales tax Bills for the first time, not having had an opportunity to speak at the second reading stage. I want to say a few words on the matter presently before us, but I might say I hold this view in regard to some of the other sales tax measures also.

SPEECH.PARA: I hasten to say that I will not vote in favour of the amendment moved by Senator Haines to return these Bills to the House of Representatives with requests. TALK.START.PARA: —A view which you did not hold in 1975.

—We are not doing it; we are asking the other place to do it.
—The Australian Democrats are seeking to hold up the passage of the Budget Bills and are asking the other place to alter them.
—Absolute rubbish!
—I am sorry, but the Democrats cannot get out of it as easily as that. I am afraid they have made a decision which is inconsistent with the stand they are taking.
—Absolute nonsense!

—I know that the Democrats are not defeating the legislation tonight, but they are holding up the implementation of the Budget measures of the Government. I must say that I find the legislation before us a particularly difficult piece of the Budget to swallow.
—But you will swallow it.

—Labor Party senators can shout their heads off. They have proved themselves now to be quite inconsistent in principle. For so many years they were so hot and strong in claiming that they would never vote against money Bills, that they would never vote against Supply Bills.
