SPEECH.PARA: Many of us in this chamber and on this side of the chamber have written to the Government about complaints concerning the provision in this legislation imposing sales tax on books and papers. A relatively small amount of money is involved at this stage, but I believe that for many of the companies engaged in the industry and people who are interested in books and papers it is a tax that will be very difficult to bear. I regret the fact that the Government has made a decision to impose a tax in that area and in other areas that are close to the needs of people. I think a good case has been made out by the Government for a general imposition of sales tax, for spreading the field of tax so that more of it is collected in sales tax, a system that is less susceptible to the evasion and avoidance problems which can arise in collecting personal income tax.

I believe that generally a case can be made out for widening the tax base. I have my own views on whether some of the areas chosen by the Government for the imposition of sales tax were wise and I believe that this one in particular was not wise. I have said so firmly in representations I have made to the Government on the matter. But I do not believe that it is incumbent on this Committee to defer and fail to pass the provisions of this legislation and to send them back to the Government. That may well be done by the Senate. If it is done I hope that the Government will take considerable notice of the expressions of sentiments felt by honourable senators, irrespective of whether they vote for or against the proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not take any notice of you, not after what you have been saying.

—That is all right. The Government always has to take notice of Senator McLaren because he makes so much noise that he is heard via the airwaves throughout the country. People have to put up with Senator McLaren's insufferable boredom morning, noon and night. I hope that some people will take the view I am expressing, a view which I sincerely hold. I have concern for some of the elements of the sales tax measures being imposed. I hope that the Government will reconsider some of them. At the same time, I hope that this Committee will not take the step of trying to superimpose its views on the Government and the House of Representatives by way of an action such as the one proposed tonight. For those reasons, I shall oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Committee is exercising its rights in seeking to refer this sales tax legislation back to the House of Representatives. I do not see that approach as being inconsistent with the attitude that has been adopted by honourable senators, even by senators such as Senator Missen. Only two or three years ago we were discussing legislation which would affect the payment of funeral benefits. That legislation formed part of the Budget.
—That was not part of the Budget.

—That legislation was part of the Budget. It was related to income. As a result of pressure being applied by Government back benchers, the Government decided to withdraw the proposal relating to funeral benefits. Of course, we recall that Senator Missen was one of the people who, in 1975, had some misgivings about the tactics being adopted by Mr Fraser in his grab for power. On several occasions in 1975 when not only the Budget but also Supply Bills were being debated in this chamber votes were cast by the then Opposition, which held a majority of seats in this chamber, for the delay and the non-passage of both the Budget and Supply Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: . What we are seeking to do here now is surely justified by the tremendous number of protests to which Senator Haines referred concerning the legislation. In the 10 years I have been a member of this chamber I have never received so much correspondence on an issue from such a wide variety of organisations, groups and people within the community. I suggest to Senator Missen and to the Government that part of our responsibility is to listen to the points of view coming from such a diverse variety of people within our society. They include small businessmen, consumer groups, manufacturers, distributors, suppliers and master builders of a whole range of products that will be affected by this Government's decision to increase and extend what can only be described as a widely based commodities tax.

I recall what the Treasurer, Mr Howard, said about this matter. Of course, this Government is becoming notorious for its double standards and its contradictory statements from one month to another. I remind the Committee, particularly Senator Missen, that on 12 March this year Mr Howard said that the Government did not wish to move towards placing a greater reliance upon indirect tax without providing a noticeable offset in personal income tax reductions. Of course, we know that the Government in these Bills has provided for the collection of $892m and there has been no offset in personal income tax. We know from representations that have been made to all honourable senators from both sides of the chamber that the low income groups will be affected, that the small producers in some of our manufacturing industries will be affected and that employment will be affected as a result of the increased charges when these wide-ranging taxes are applied. I find it particularly offensive that we should be increasing taxation in the home building materials area, that we should be increasing taxation on printed materials, clothing and the hundreds and hundreds of items that have been suggested in the Government's sales tax legislation.

I think the Australian Democrats have had some difficulties in reconciling their position. I can understand that they are reflecting, as they should, the demands that have been made of them by many groups within the Australian community. In fact, if they had not responded I am sure that many people who supported them in the last election would have been disappointed. Many people on my side of politics also would have been disappointed because the Australian community believes that if the Democrats, Senator Harradine and the Labor Party combine the Government will be forced to re-examine its existing legislation. The Senate, as a House of review, is entitled to say that the Government should have a fresh look at this matter. I remind Senator Missen that the Budget which has not yet been passed by this place provides for a substantial domestic surplus. If we were to refuse to approve all of these Bills tonight or in the future the Budget considerations would in no way be affected. Such action would affect only the Government's strategy of taking money out of the Australian community in order to minimise the effect of capital inflow from overseas. It would in no way affect the income and expenditure aspects of the Budget which is still before the Parliament.

It is proper for us to look at these Bills in the way that has been suggested in the motion and not to see this proposal in the context of denying Supply. The proposal does not affect the Supply component of the Budget at all; in no way does it affect the Supply situation. The Supply Bills will pass. The Bills we are considering deal with the collection of a tax. They do not affect the Budget; they affect only the Budget strategy. The Government claims that it is concerned about inflation. However, it is conceded by the Government's own spokesman that the inflation rate will be affected by these sales tax provisions by anything up to one per cent. Government senators should be consistent when they look at the way in which the majority of members in this place seek to refer this matter back to the House of Representatives for further consideration. Even Senator Missen accepts that there is a case for some amendment to the sales tax legislation. He admits that and yet he suggests that we are acting improperly and wrongly by sending the matter back to the House of Representatives for further consideration. After all, no basic difference would be made to the overall Budget considerations if these decisions were arrived at.

I will not weary the Senate by referring to all the correspondence we have received from a variety of organisations. We have even received correspondence from Rotary clubs. Organisations that print small magazines have asked us in this place to exercise our power, not of veto but our power to re-examine the Government's legislation.We have had groups from Queensland. We have had organisations associated with printing, international public relations, master builders, suppliers of building materials and a whole number of manufacturers who have asked us to exercise, in some cases, a power of veto. That is not what is proposed by the Democrats in this motion. The motion is asking us to send the legislation back to the House of Representatives with a request that it have another look at the proposal which is repugnant to the Australian community, to the Australian Labor Party and, I hope, to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make some points in relation to item 51, having spent most of my working life until now in education, having written books and having been, just shortly before I took my seat as a senator, a director of a publishing firm. I think this area which the Australian Democrats have taken as one of four areas of basic need within the community is one which will hit not simply those people who are engaged in the publication of books and not simply those who are currently involved with organisations. I read from the principal Act of 1935 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Books, pamphlets, leaflets, periodicals or magazines issued or to be issued by or on behalf of an organization which is not carried on for the profit of individuals . . .

In other words, what we are picking up here and taxing for the first time are all of those methods by which organisations, charities and a whole range of service organisations within the community carry out their work. They will, in fact, have an impost put on them by the Government. They will be taxed by the Government in carrying out their work, which is not for their profit. In most cases, given the wide range of organisations in our community, those organisations are specifically there for the benefit of the community.

The point I make is this: This Government preaches an enormous amount about private enterprise, about people helping themselves, about people helping in the community and about people getting out and doing something for themselves. When people do that they are taxed. We have the most absurd context of taxing such individuals and such organisations. In fact, when people finally get off their backsides and do something we say: 'Well, jolly good on you, you are going to be taxed because of it'. Up to now they have not been taxed and that is as it should be. We hope that under the Constitution and by the quite legitimate means which the Democrats have adopted that is, a referral which is not a blocking which we have sworn that we will not do, they will not be taxed. I remind not only the government but also the Australian Labor Party which says that it will be in government in two years that we respect the Budgets of the Government in the lower House.

We are quite properly making requests. We presume that in two years we will probably be making requests on identical items, to a Labor Government because the Labor Party has not yet said that it will take all of these imposts off. We will be making requests, as it is the right of this chamber to do. We hope that if the House of Representatives respects this chamber it will deal with the requests on this item and on the other items that we will propose for consideration. I urge the Government to look again and make sure in whatever way it possibly can that it will stop taxing all of those areas of knowledge within the community and all of those services and support organisations which are so much the lifeblood of the community such as ours. They certainly should not be taxed in carrying out those types of service activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reply very briefly to Senator Missen's remarks. I must reply to Senator Missen's spurious arguments and his attempt to mislead the Senate and the public again. The Bills to which we are seeking to append requests are not Supply Bills. They do not affect the survival of the Government or the process of government. The only effect on the fiscal outcome, the final Budget outcome, would be to reduce the domestic surplus from $1,500m to $1,000m. In so doing they would also stimulate economic activity, the need for which is already becoming apparent and will become progressively more apparent as the year goes on. A close analogy to the rejection of all of these Bills is, of course, the situation involving the Medibank levy of 1974. In both cases-the Medibank levy and the whole package of Bills we are debating tonight-the Bills in question are Bills to raise revenue. There is this important exception: The Senate of 1974, dominated by the Liberal and National Country parties, stopped the government of the day from keeping its pre-election promises. What this request and the other action which will be taken on these Bills seek to do is to stop the Fraser Government from breaking its election promises. I also add in reply to another of Senator Missen's spurious arguments-strictly applied to these Bills only; that the passage is being held up and that that is important-the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) do not become operative until 1 January 1982. That argument is even more spurious than the rest of the arguments he used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. I just indicate that I will be supporting the request proposed by Senator Haines. —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. This amendment would add a new section 38A to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill making a series of amendments to the First Schedule of the parent Act. The amendment which has been circulated is intended to be, as it were, the second leg of the double, the first leg of which was the series of requests which we have just passed. The subject matter of this amendment is directed at exactly the same result which the Australian Democrats have shown that they hold dear, namely, the exemption from sales tax of books, newspapers, wrapping materials, clothing, footwear and building materials for private dwellings. Whereas the requests to Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A-9A) were designed to exempt these items by removing them from the ambit of the sales tax Bills, this amendment achieves the same result in a different way by removing them from the ambit of the sales tax Bills by way of redefining the content of the items referred to in those sales tax Bills.

The proposal that has been put to the Senate is in fact a development of a suggestion originally made in passing by Senator Harradine in his original widely circulated letter arguing for a split in the sales tax Bills so as to enable questions relating to exemptions and classifications to be dealt with separately. The proposal, if I may illustrate briefly with one example what I mean, runs something like this: In clause 5 of the sales tax Bills there is a reference to items in Schedule 1 of the exemptions and classifications Bill in respect of which the new tax imposed by Bills 1A-9A will bite. One such example of a Schedule item is item 54 which refers to 'newspapers'. What this amendment proposes in relation to that item is to take item 54 but to delete from item 54 the reference to the word 'newspapers'. That is to take it out of 54-to denude 54, as it were, of any content at all-and then to reinsert the subject matter, 'newspapers', in the First Schedule as in this case, new item 155.

The reason for this peculiar sounding exercise, which is technically complex on the face of it, is really quite simple although not all that simple at 10 minutes to midnight, I readily acknowledge. The object of the exercise is, by a different route, to accomplish the same result, I readily acknowledge, as has begun to be accomplished by the requests we previously passed. In this case it is getting there by reshaping the content of the particular schedule items. In the case of the sales tax Bill requests, it was getting there by removing those items themselves from the bite of the taxation there imposed.

What is to be said against these amendments? In the first place, I suppose it might be suggested that it is not technically within the competence of the Senate to amend, as distinct from requesting amendments of, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill at all. This is a point that I would not have thought would be made tonight had I not heard the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) making much of it in the context of his earlier remarks in relation to Senator Harradine's motion. He did so notwithstanding the very long practice of this Senate, which dates back to at least 1960 and is the subject of a paragraph in Odgers, at page 390 of the current edition, explaining its basis. The Attorney-General made the point, the relevance of which, it must be acknowledged, did not quite seem to appreciate in the context of the present Bill, that the exemptions and classifications measure might properly be regarded as a money Bill to the extent that, whatever its form, it does in practice achieve the result, when one shuffles items in and out of the schedules, of determining the imposition of taxation. That is a fair point legally to make about the character of that Bill and I must confess that I have always been somewhat puzzled by the ready and apparently universal acceptance of exemptions and classifications Bills as being non-money Bills.

I acknowledge the force of that point and if anyone on either side of the chamber wants to insist upon it I indicate that the Opposition is perfectly happy to move exactly the same amendment in the form of a request or, if one wants to cover all possible contingencies and give Mr Odgers or his successors something to write about in the next edition, maybe one could move the amendment both technically in that form and also, in the alternative, in the form of a request to the House of Representatives. So let us not be deterred or deflected from the substantive issue before us by procedural questions of this kind.

Dear Senator Jessop I refer to your letter of 10 September 1981 relating to the sales tax changes in which you raised two points following my letter of 26 August 1981.

The first point refers to the date of effect of the changes to correct anomalies and inconsistencies and the increased rates which apply from 19 August 1981. As I said, the changes were made along traditional lines and there are innumerable precedents for this course of action.

There are good reasons for this traditional approach. These reasons include protection of the revenue against hoarding and other special arrangements for movement of stock past the taxing point. There is also a question of maintaining equity in the market place. To illustrate the last point, a wholesaler with access to large stocks could, with forewarning, undercut his competitors in the market place quite seriously if he was able to move those stocks through the taxing point prior to an announced change of rate taking effect.

This traditional approach is evidenced in the sales tax area and also in the customs area. A similar approach has been taken by the Government in relation to ACT Stamp Duties. There are devices available to people to protect themselves against changes in these laws if the changes are preannounced. Not only does the use of such devices adversely affect the revenue but people who choose to use them gain an unfair advantage in the market over their competitors.

Notwithstanding this traditional approach and the reasons for it, the Government recognised that both industry and the Taxation Office would require time to implement the proposals regarding the broadening of the tax base to come into effect from 1 January 1982.

Those considerations lead the Government to depart from the traditional method of implementation. I might add that the proposed rate of tax at 2.5 per cent does not provide a great deal of scope for abuse or for unfair competition and when this is taken into account I think you will agree that there were sound reasons for departing from the traditional method.
For these reasons I do not agree that there is any inconsistency in the Government's approach on the Sales Tax Bills.

You also queried the postscript to my letter of 26 August 1981. Dear Senator Jessop,
Sales Tax Amendments

Reference is made to the telephone conversation between your Mr B. O'Farrell and Mr S. Bladwell, Chairman, Sydney Sales Tax Discussion Group. Mr Bladwell has asked me as a member of the Group to respond on the Group's behalf.

(These examples are attached as Appendix B).

Apart from these problems there is another serious consequence caused by the retrospectivity of these amendments. From 19 August 1981 until the bills receive royal assent the existing legislation still stands. Accordingly taxpayers who 'cover' themselves by charging the higher sales tax rates (here I should mention that the Commissioner of Taxation is actively encouraging this course of action) are in breach of s. 70D Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1). This section prohibits persons from charging a greater amount of sales tax than that which they are liable to pay under the provisions of the legislation.

Even those taxpayers whose products only increased 2 1/2 percentage points have been inconvenienced by the suddenness of the announcement. These people had no time in which to alter their computer programs and invoicing procedures. Other taxpayers had goods invoiced and orders assembled but which were held up because of the recent Transport Workers Union strike only to find that the company's sales tax liability in respect of such goods had generally increased. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. SPEECH.PARA: The Government well recognises the problems of certain persons who may have arranged to purchase goods which were previously exempt from tax but which are now to be taxed or goods which are to be taxed at a higher rate. Whilst the Government has some sympathy for persons who find themselves in these situations, the sales tax liability question arises on the date which the sale of goods takes place and not when the order is placed or when a deposit or part payment has been made. This leads me to the major purpose of my speech. During my speech at the second reading stage I was critical of the quality of advice coming from departments to Ministers and, in particular, the wisdom of the advice presented to the Treasurer on the proposed sales tax increases. In that speech I characterised that advice as being short sighted and lacking thoroughness when it came to looking at the consequences of introducing these sales tax increases. An anomalous situation, which I will refer to in detail in a few moments, is further proof. In an attempt to overcome anomalies which the Treasury believes to be contained in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, other anomalies have arisen. I believe that they should not have arisen. The anomaly to which I refer relates to sections 119 and 119A of the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. What I am disturbed about, and I am furious about it, is the fact that it was I, in the first place, who pointed out that we could do precisely what Senator Evans did to- night, and that is advance amendments to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill but I said that we should do that as a last resort. I will eat the words if I have said them wrongly. If the Labor Party does not ultimately support the divisions of the Bills as I propose to divide them it truly has, by its actions tonight, sold out the people of Australia in respect of these sales tax Bills.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 20 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister advise whether the Queensland Government intends to introduce limited numbers of imported African Nile perch into Queensland waterways for biological evaluation.

(2) Can the Minister guarantee that the strictest quarantine and security precautions will be enforced to prevent a repetition of the European carp disaster, particularly when it requires only one unscrupulous person to release young perch into another stream and bearing in mind the female perch can produce up to 12 million eggs at each spawning.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At the tenth meeting of the Australian Fisheries Council in Darwin on 12 September 1980, the Queensland Minister for Maritime Services and Tourism, the Honourable M. D. Hooper, sought the approval of Council to the import of a few hundred Nile perch for research into their suitability for eventual release in Queensland waters as a food and sport fish. He offered to establish a research station with proper and adequate safeguards to enable research by Queensland scientists for two or three years to establish whether Nile perch should be allowed into Australian waters. At the end of the trial period the project will be evaluated by Standing Committee and Council before a final decision on release into Australian waters is made.
Council agreed to the importation by Queensland of a limited number of Nile perch, under adequate security to prevent their escape, for research into their suitability as a food and sport fish.
The Queensland Government has not yet submitted an application to the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to import the fish.

(2) In seeking the approval of the Australian Fisheries Council Mr Hooper emphasised that there would be adequate safeguards and security measures. Any importation would be subject to quarantine requirements.
